number of helpful: 212 of 232 people (91%) found this review helpful9 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 26, 2015
												If Magic : The Gathering and Dungeons & Dragons have a child, Card Hunter would be it.At its core, Card Hunter is a pen and paper RPG with a twist. You play all of your action through cards that obtained from equiping items. So, different items had different cards.Pro :1. Free to play with cash to speedup your progress.2. Excellent Multiplayer with automatic matchmaking, ladder, rewards, etc.3. Easy to learn, hard to master.4. Excellent Singleplayer/Coop campaign.Con :1. Currently only 3 class and 3 races. Based on D&D mechanic, this is rather small2. There is no way to gain cash currency for free other than joining guild (Five 5$ redeemable coupon that only guild master decide who gonna get it). You only get what they give it to you while doing tutorial (spend it wisely).3. Some dungeon are locked with cash currency. While there is no item that cannot be obtained by free players, the locked dungeon guaranteed to get an epic item for the first time completed.Some tips :1. Choose your starting party wisely. While you can change it anytime you want, it can be a hassle to level up it again. A popular combination is dwarf warrior, human priest, and elf wizard but I dont recommend it (see tips 2). My personal favourite is elf warrior, human priest and gnome wizard that kinda hard early on. Check the wiki for some insight. http://wiki.cardhuntria.com/wiki/Cardhuntria:Community_portal2. You get a free multiplayer pack at Renown 5. Try to raise your renown to that level by doing campaign first. The pack is consist of dwarf warior, human priest and elf wizard with reasonable equipment to get you started multiplayer. Multiplayer character is interchangeable with the campaign character, that is why I suggest not to take that character as your starting character because you get it free later. But, recruiting level 1 character is only 10 gold. So do what you seem it fit.3. A lot of people is asking this, so I gonna write it here. You can start selling your equipment at Renown 7. I dont recommend to sell equipment because you maybe need it sometimes later for the campaign.4. When you get your pizza, the game make you spend it at that time. Just dont ! Close the client and you get the pizza without spending it. You can spend it later for whatever seems the best for you.

number of helpful: 72 of 90 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 4, 2015
												Part of me wants to give this game a recommend, and rate it about 8.0/10.  If you're looking for a good, fun board game/card game/strategy amalgamation, this is a pretty sharp little package.  The script is witty and funny, the gameplay is tight and well-designed, the game looks beautiful in it's simple cartoon style.  What's not to love?The problem is the way the financial end is set up.  Now, you can play through the single-player campagin and have all the fun you want with multi-player for free... but if you want to play the additional Treasure Hunt add-on content, through the base game and its two expansions, the in-game pricing is $20+$13+13, for a total of $46!  I felt bad about getting so much fun out of this game for free, and was looking to throw the developers some cash.  I also wanted to complete all of the Treasure Hunts and get the achievements for doing so.  But no way in hell am I paying $46 for it.  Somewhere in the neighborhood of $10-$15 sounds about right, and maybe $5-$10 if you could grab it on a Steam sale.But it won't ever be on a Steam sale, because the prices are all in-game.  The Steam page simply lists it as a free game, without the pricing tiers or the ability to buy it from Steam.And to be honest, some of the other the achievements are practically an impossibility.  It's pretty rare to get an epic item, and more difficult to get a legendary.  I have a handful of epics after 80 hours game time and maybe 2-5 legendaries.  But to get the hundreds listed as a part of the achievement?  Probably won't ever happen.  Especially if you're not paying a monthly membership fee on top of everything else, which gives you an additional piece of higher level gear with every loot chest.  It's a fun game... but it's not big or deep enough to keep me playing for dozens to hundreds of hours a month as a part of some subscription model.  It certainly doesn't have the scope that World of Warcraft did back in its day.The devs would have kept me playing longer, and spending some money, if they hadn't made the non-free full version so ridiculousy expensive.So enjoy the campaign, get what you can out of it, and be done with it.  If you really want to give the devs some money, you can always buy in-game currency to unlock a few of the Treasure Hunts or a couple of extra costume/characters.UPDATE:  I had originally given this a marginal thumbs down, but just recently changed it to a thumbs up because of the comments from Sgt. Buttersworth [308] below.  It turns out you can get all of the DLC for cheaper than the fees they charge in-game buying them separately as stand alone bundles.  My advice is to check out the game for free.  If you like it, by the time you start hitting the optional add-ins, the thing to do is click on the pizza slices at the top menubar.  Instead of buying the Basic Edition for $20, the AotA Bundle for $13, and the Citadel Bundle for $13, simply buy 690 slices of pizza for $20.You can then use those 690 slices of pizza (plus the pizza slices you get from playing the free part of the game) to purchase the treasure hunts in bundles at the following rates: 300 for the Basic Edition treasure hunts, 150 for the AotA hunts, and 150 for the Citdel hunts.  This will get you all of the expansion DLC for $20 instead of $46, and you'll still have some extra pizza left for a few costumes.  Certainly not as many as if you'd bought the DLC's separately, but they're all cosmetic & ultimately unnessary imo.  You also won't have access to the one-month Club memberships that will give you extra loot, but those are also not necessary.  If you want to spend the $46, you can, and the difference will be a bunch more figures/costumes, and three months of Club memberships (one month for each of the bundles).I'd say that $20 is more what the game is worth, and for that price you can pretty much experience everything the game has to offer.  You can always buy the Club memberships later with additional pizza.  80 pizza will get you a week (and if you don't buy anything else, you'll have enough pizza left for a week membership with the 690 you've bought for $20).  After that, it's about 300 pizza per month with pizza priced at 330 slices for $10.So to sum up... play the free game.  If you like it, buy all of the treasure hunts in pizza bundles after buying 690 slices for $20... which will also afford you a 1-week Club Membership.  After that, $10 will give you a month of Club Membership if you desire to keep it going, with some pizza leftover each month.Purchasing that way will give you a better deal than buying all of the bundles for cash at a total of $46.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2015
												I strongly recommend this free game, it's a high quality cards/strategy game with some RPG elements that offers a lot of content for free.It's not pay to win, you can pay to get some extra stuff like costumes, more challenges or some loot when you open chests but it doesn't give you any advantage against other players (well, you might collect some useful items a bit faster, that's all). I decided to pay (I got the Basic Edition) after 30 hours of gameplay and not because I need it but because I feel the developers really deserve it for this awesome game and I think I'll keep playing it for many more hours.Besides the long solo campaign it offers a great multiplayer experience with a simple but effective automatic matching system and a rating that gets updated after each battle. There are also leagues with different game modes.All in all, a fantastic free game that shouldn't go without notice.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												This is essentially a pay to win game. The tutorial is well done and quickly gets you into the game. The loot is varied and interesting. Which makes you want to play more. But as soon as you get into multiplayer, you quickly realize that you need to pay in order to compete. The prices are steep too. Balance is nigh impossible because of how the game is centered around card drops.Single player campaigns are a grindfest. Campaigns are well made, and the level design is well thought out. They are fun, interesting, varied and challenging. Unfortunately you need to pay to proceed to higher level campaigns. After buying the campaign you still have to grind, pay to grind. There is a 1 day cool down and wait to for all the campaigns too.This game has so much potential if it do away with the f2p model and just be a proper paid subscription game. After all there is no way you can survive without paying.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
												tl;dr: pay to win.This is a decent concept held down by a pay to win system that undermines strategy and hours spent getting loot. Loot that is trumped by shop gear which costs you hundreds to thousands of gold to buy, but then is sold for 2... 2 gold.Another annoying "feature" is that players quit the game when you're winning and you have to sit there for 2 minutes waiting when it is clear that they aren't coming back.  The game has a 20 minute timer that is laughable. Most players are quick and every now and then you need some time to think, but then there are the players that spend what seems like ages trying to make up their mind on how to move... And this is even in the higher ranks where you're supposed to be playing against players who earned their way up in rank. But this could be another side effect of the pay to win mentality of the game.It grasps you for a while but then it just stalls at this pay to win ceiling that makes the game hard to enjoy, then you get the slow players that make you feel like scratching out your eyeballs. 4/10.

												Pay to win.My first multiplayer game at level 6, my opponent made what I thought was a tactical mistake. He rushed in with one warrior against my entire team of three. I realized it wasn't a mistake when he moved 5 times in one turn with that one character, killing my own warrior using abilities and a lightsaber that took half my life in one hit, then jumping away to the control point so I had no chance to even hit him the next turn. content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												As a game developer, I am very choosy about my games.  I prefer games that require analysis, meaningful choice, a strategic, non-frenetic pace and that offer enough surprises that the outcome is never certain. Card Hunter is a turn based delight; a success in all of these areas.  It offers deep mechanics, yet is easy to pick up.  It can be as serious or casual as you like and is great to play with your friends or kids.  Co-op is now in and super fun!Best of all, it is the rarest of unicorns: being truly free to play and NOT pay to win.  I do however encourage you to buy the expansion packs because supporting games and developers like this is the only way we get more games of this caliber.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
												DnD styled RPG in form of a card/tabletop game. You build your "decks" by equipping your characters with items (equipping an axe gives you 3 Chop cards and so on)PROS- The game looks pretty, like an old school tabletop game.- Lots of items allowing for diverse deck building.- Fair progression system, makes you want to keep playing to get moar loot.- The game ain't too hard nor too easy. Good challenge!- Very cool ftp model. You can have tons of fun without spending a penny, even in MP.- Simple and effective UI and HUD, I appreciate how devs sped up certain parts and made the game smoother. PC card/tabletop games usually have those extra unnecessarry animations. Not here though.CONS- Currently there are only 3 classes (and 3 races). The game balances it by forcing you to regularly revise and rebuild your deck to optimize it for various scenarios, so it doesn't get boring too quick. Couldn't find any info if they will add new ones.- Because of how the base game mechanics work (SP), they don't work that well in MP, especially in Co-op mode. Only one player can play per turn, so it could get a bit stale for others. Still, if you play with friends you won't mind it too much.Definitely recommending, if you like Hand of Fate, Guild of Dungeoneering, Talisman - you'll love this. Tons of fun and FREE!EDIT: typos

content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												Genre - F2P (with optional paid elements) Fantasy turn based battle gameI have only played single player and my positive review is based on that. I am having problems with queue times of up to 30 minutes, but hope they will fix this issue soon, and will ignore this with my rating.I am a fan of board games but without a good RPG friend base, I have to turn to computer games to get my fix. This game manages to satisfy my cravings well. You will use three characters throughout (Warrior, Mage and Priest, but no Rogue yet...). You fight turn based battles as part of a series of quests. You gain loot and items after each victory. As your characters level up, you get to equip more stuff. Each item has a set of cards attached and these are used for each turn based batle. They will move, protect, boost, heal and attack in various ways. As a result you will develop unique characters with their own advantages and disadvantages (some negative traits have to be played). The game story plays as if you are playing a tabletop RPG (reminding me of the Knights of pen and paper). This works quite nicely and creates a more immersive experience. I wish that pizza girl would stop distracting the DM!A great game that gives enough enjoyment as F2P to justify you splashing a bit of cash to get extra quests and skins for your toons.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
												For what it is, this game receives an odd amount of universal praise, and it's frankly strange there isn't more criticism. I suspect this is because most don't play more than an hour or two, which is when freemium games really start to reveal themselves. So here we go:Difficulty. The game starts off as a very easy ride, before suddenly gutpunching you with a huge difficulty spike when without warning you're going to find that you constantly need to customize your deck to each fight. This isnt necessarily a bad thing in itself, but chances are you simply don't have the options you need to actually carry out the strategy. Building a specific type of deck to counter a mission can become downright impossible because you simply dont have the cards to make it. The loot system is completely rng (though you can inject money to expidate the process).But hold, you can buy items from the in game shop! Too bad the in game currency to buy these items is also only obtained via rng. So you have to grind to obtain it. But you can only play each level once per day. So fine, maybe you'll go into that mission with only a couple of counter items. But whoops, you didn't draw the right cards. Back to the start for you.As the game goes on, it's clear that they gave up on any semblance of caring about balance and just throw a dozen enemies with hands 4 times the size of yours with blatantly overpowered cards. Maybe you decide you'll use a lot of cards that push your enemy back so you can avoid damage. Too bad, the enemy has all range cards and tons of movement along with armor cards. You need to reach the end of the board before the enemy can call for help? Build a movement heavy deck. Oh wait, the enemies inexplicably have cards that do 12+ damage. Guess you better go back and do more grinding. And if a single one of your party dies, it gives the enemy enough points to win instantly.But what's that? You got a piece of powerful gear? Too bad, you can't use it until you're a much higher level. And on the off chance you recieve more than one of these, you're gated from using them through 'power tokens' so you have to grind even more to use it. The level ups do not come quickly after you've played to this point.I hear tons of people claim that game is in no way pay to win. So lets go down the freemium checklist:-Forcing daily logins to make progress-Time gating content-Premium currency-In game currency that's worth far less than than premium currency to the point it's a joke-High amounts of content locked to free players-VIP Scheme-Guaranteed strong gear for paying players-Horrendous real money to currency ratioYou can try to excuse the gear issue as 'anyone can get the rarest gear', but it is an incredibly time consuming and rng process to those not willing to drop the excessive amounts of money the game wants you to. The game might well have been good, if they'd just bit the bullet and put a price on it. But as it stands, free to play claims yet another victim.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2015
												SKIP DOWN TILL YOU DO NOT SEE MY IMAGINARY GUEST FOR QUESTIONS ABOUT THE F2P STUFF.What I was expectinga casual game that was attempting to jump on the DnD Bandwagon for people afraid of pen-and-paper and its complexity.I do not think I have been so wrong and so happy with that ever before in my life. I think I need assistance on this review, so let me nab this radish farmer to help me get my thoughts out.Originally posted by Gaming Peasant: Wha is dis den?Card Hunter is a High-Fantasy, Card-based TBS/Pen 'n' Paper RPG.Originally posted by Gaming Peasant: Den its' a casual bloke's DnD den? Why are yas playing dis?Ah, but that is where you are wrong. Yes, it's High-Fantasy, but that is not quite the setting. You are a guest in the home of Gary and Melvin. Gary is a beginning Game Master (GM), and Melvin is the assholish, but veteran, GM. Gary is the one hosting this game and running the singleplayer (according to my playtime spanning across two days), while Melvin is the prime definition of a neckbeard that needs to remember that games are supposed to be fun.Originally posted by Gaming Peasant: Roight, so it's not a standed computa game. How does it play?Good Question, my Linen-garbed friend! The game is sectioned into rounds. Each player takes turns, playing a single attack, movement, or spell card per turn. This continues until one player is out of action cards, and passes. If the other players have action cards, they can continue playing until all are out, which the final person to pass declares the round as ended.Originally posted by Gaming Peasant: Sounds simple. methinks there is more to dis den dat! You have no idea. There is a ton to manipulate and do and use to your advantage, from trapping floors and laying curses upon your foes, to Objectives within the field of battle. Adding to the mix are Traits and Handicaps, which can buff and debuff your team and your enemies to turn the tables in your favor!Originally posted by Gaming Peasant: Okay. Carry on, I need some amusement while I harvest me crops.At the beginning, you recruit three party members. You can choose from 3 races and 3 classes. This may seem a little lackluster, but this actually keeps things simple enough for the novice RPG player, and yet still adds a good amount of strategy to your party. Dwarves are very tough, but are slow. Humans are decent in both movement and toughness, while Elves are very fast and have the bone structure of a sparrow.Originally posted by Gaming Peasant: Wot of magic usage? Most of dese type of fings 'ave them differ in ability...That's the cool thing. All 3 races are completly capable of rocking out as a mage due to how the magic and attacks are handled. This leads me to the classes; The Warrior, the Paladin and the Mage. Sorry, thieves, the healer is more important, and Elf Warriors are pretty much the same.The Warrior is able to wear heavy armor, can wield THREE weapons (Maybe the dwarves have prehensile beards?), and generally hit like a speeding truck.The Paladin meshes Might and Magic nicely, heals and buffs their teammates, and can even lay down the smiting via curses!The humble mage is a master of long-distance combat, but shines when you can hurl opponents with Telekenetics, block pathways with lava flows, and fling all sorts of elemental bolts, among many, MANY cooler things!Originally posted by Gaming Peasant: How easy is it to pick up? me kin may try dis! All that is needed is a basic reading ability, and elementary arithmatic for planning.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Now let me get to the F2P aspects:It is handled almost as good as Team Fortress 2 before the Robot Update. I♥♥♥♥♥♥you notThey introduce it throughout the campaign, but not only is almost all of it optional, but when they do? FREE IN-GAME CURRENCY IS DROPPED ON YOU AND YOU CAN JUST SKIP THAT♥♥♥♥♥♥OFTEN.Rather get a free week of club membership? DO IT.Like the standard look of your characters? PASS THE COSTUME SHOP.Rather test your luck on a bunch of chests than go do the treasure dungeons? GAMBLE AWAY!Even the Expansions can be attained from completing the Campaign (To my knowledge)! I cannot stress this enough: These devs know how to do the Free to Play model right, and when I get the spare dosh, I am definitely rewarding these people not only for making this wonderful game, but also for treating the consumer so well that you WANT to spend money on their free game. The only major hitch is that the voices can get annoying (Melvin, I swear to god if you keep being a douchenozzle I will give your hatchback a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ hydrochloric acid bath), and that if you are not really interested in High Fantasy stuff, you are gonna be bored out of your skull.If those don't bother you, Give it a try.

number of helpful: 15 of 15 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												First, to address the sharkbear in the room; yes, this is F2P in the modern sense; some content is locked behind a paywall, there's a premium currency with which to purchase cosmetics, a VIP system, and there's systems to "encourage" daily logins.So it's not free?  Well, the price for all the paywalled content is not egregious, and if you believe game devs don't deserve any money at all, you and I are in fundamental disagreement.  The simple fact is, once you've paid for the extra adventures, they're available permanently, so that's fine by me.  The VIP system is nice enough that I've subscribed a few times, but considering the loot earned is so amazingly RNG-based, and the fact that some of the best items are easy to get hold of (bejewelled shortsword, I'm looking at you), calling the game pay-to-win would be lunacy.  As for cosmetics, well, if you've got spare cash and feel like supporting the devs, why not?  I'd sooner spend my cash on the VIP system now and again, but everyone's got their own priorities, right?Right, so, is it good?  Well, I wouldn't have bothered writing all this if it wasn't.  It's fun as a game, with a healthy dose of goofy self-deprecation in its writing.  The mechanics of the card game/board game crossover are well thought out, and while you'll definitely lose sometimes due to the RNG, you'll also have some lucky saves and hits (which won't stick in your memory as well).The community is generally positive, at least in cooperative PVE (I've barely touched PVP), and most people are helpful, rather than aggressive.About the only major issue is that there really is a degree of grind to this, despite the protestations of some long-term players.  As the loot is completely RNG-based, and many adventures (or even particular levels) require quite specific approaches, it's easy to reach a point where you simply cannot beat a board because the equipment you have is either massively inappropriate, or just too weak.  The only way to get the appropriate equipment is to repeatedly re-run earlier levels (or have a go at PVP).  I'd guess this is where accusations of P2W come in, but the bonus equipment merely expedites the grinding by a small amount.  There is a certain satisfaction in honing efficiency in different levels, particularly as you gradually get equipment that suits each level piece by piece, but I've sometimes found myself wishing to program a bot to re-run levels automatically.All in all, it's great fun, but sooner or later, you'll find that you can't progress without grinding (even with the VIP system), and at that point you may find the fun rapidly runs out, or you might enjoy experimenting, improvising and getting help from a good community to make further progress.  For me it was the latter, but I don't doubt that it's not the same for everyone.

number of helpful: 58 of 95 people (61%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2015
												More frustrating than fun.   Too much reliance on getting good results from random rolls/draws/loots.  Frustrating as hell to be in a difficult fight, and your warrior draws no attacking cards for 3 rounds in a row, while at the same time your healer doesn't draw any healing cards. And when you do finally draw that much needed attack card, your opponent blocks it with an armor or shield card.  It's worse than bad rolls  in a real DnD game. Here you have to randomly get the right card, then if the target has armor or a shield, you have to randomly succeed against his block.  In DnD you can always move and attack, and even if your attack rolls were bad, you weren't hamstrung by not having a card that allowed you to attack.   If you were unlucky not get good loot drops, it makes your life even worse.  Your cards available to you are dependant on the loot you get. Also loot that worked well in one adventure, may not work well in the next one. The game won't let you sell usable items for quite a while into the game. Meaning you have tons of junk in your inventory that you'll never use and can't sell to buy stuff you really want. The sterotypical dungeon master schtick with Gary and Melvin is amusing at first, but after a few adventures you start wishing they'd just shut up.   The whole cardstock aesthetic has it's own charm too. Naturally being an online game you have to deal with full servers or servers being down.  It's worth trying for free, but I'd rather play a proper traditional RPG than this, personally.  It's kind of funny to me, that I feel like I would like this game better if I had never played actual pen and paper RPGs before.

Posted: September 17, 2016
												What a great game.  I've been playing for a couple years and I play it every day, at least once a day, to catch the Loot Fairy.  A game can take between 5 minutes and 20ish minutes.  You create a dungeon delving party of wizards, priests and warriors from the classic rpg races.  Then you equip them.  Your equipment dictates the composition of cards in your deck and your deck dictates how well, or poorly, your party performs in the dungeon modules.  Rewards for winning the adventures are stronger weapons, armor and items and, hence, better cards in your deck.  Of course your dudes level up and move on to more challenging modules.  I'm certain that if you played D&D, or any table-top fantasy RPG, in the 80s you will find this game very, very nostalgic and fun.  You will also immediately recognize your AI opponents, Gary and Melvin, from your youth!This is the only time I've written a review for a game on Steam and I play many games on Steam.What a great game.danntbilll

content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
												A turn based strategic card game, with some RPG elements. This game is not for everyone, people with a bit of patience and love for strategy games will enjoy this. The concept of the game is simple, you have three races to choose from, with each race having it's advantages and disadvantages. Then you have three types of heroes for each race. Mage, Warrior and Healer. You get a set of cards for each of them and as you progress you get better cards. At the start of the round you are given random cards from you deck, that you can play out on the board. The campaign keeps you entertained, you can complete the story, but you can't complete the game 100 percent unless you are willing to spend money. Online multiplayer is pretty smooth and keeps you entertained with competitive matchmaking and rare item drops. Give this game a try once.

												Fantastic game made better by co-oping with a friend. Card Hunter is a turn-based tactical board-game, played by creating a deck of cards you get by equipping loot items. It's intuitive and simple to learn, even for people unfamiliar with this type of strategy game. There's a campaign story that is simplistic but entertaining, and meshes well with the cartoonish graphics. It's sort of a D&D parody, but not in the sense that it mocks the genre so much as it embraces the sterotypes.It is truly free-to-play, and though there are some paid aspects you can indulge in if you wish, there is no pay-to-win leaderboard aspect. Oh, and this game does have dice rolls. Some days you'll get lucky. Some days you'll get milumbarred. It happens.

number of helpful: 17 of 23 people (74%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 26, 2015
												Card Hunter is a combination of a traditional collectable card game mixed with tabletop gameplay delivered to in such a wonderful presentation. Presented in the form of a tabletop game board, each campaign is several levels or floors deep. Pitting you up against different foes with different sets of cards.You are introduced to all the mechanics in a great way using the early missions as their conduit. You'll also unlock each of your starting party members one at a time over the course of the first hour or so of the game. Each of the character classes are: Warrior, Priest, Wizard and each of those can be one of these 3 races: Human, Elf, Dwarf. This gives you a chance to learn the basics with each one as you play. Tutorials tend to make or break strategy games, but Card Hunter does it in a simple and engaging way. The single player campaigns are all a part of an overarching story where the brothers Gary and Melvin take a tongue in cheek approach of the dungeon master and player roles. This makes each encounter feel like a real tabletop RPG, especially with the art assets and introductions for each campaign. Each of these campaigns is picked from an overworld map that looks like an actual paper map with little dungeons and shops that pop up as you progress. The attention to detail is one of the things I find the most fascinating about this game. Each character, game piece, card all look like real game pieces. Blue Manchu did a great job with the art direction on this and it shows.The gameplay here is the star. Mechanically it's very deep, with 1000's of items that alter your deck. Instead of the traditional collectable card game trope of opening card packs and building a deck. You instead must equip each of you characters with one of those many items. Each item is a set of cards for your deck. So as you outfit your party with better weapons your card pool will get stronger as well. These items are obtained from completing the single player campaigns, playing multiplayer, or purchasing chests with a paid currency.By making the deck building mechanic tie into the itemization of your party it makes you make decisions that normally you wouldn't do. As you progress, each character is given a certain number of major and minor power tokens, which gate the gear you can use. You will find some of the best loot requires some of these tokens when you're equipping your character. This prevents you from making a character to powerful. Much like traditional tcg's or ccg's would limit the number of copies of certain cards in a deck, this mechanic is essentially doing the same thing. Though what happens here is it forces you to make some tough decisions. For instance, do you equip the laser weapon with 6 awesome attacks or the divine item that gives you some extra heals. The way this customization works adds a nice layer of depth to the strategy of this game and one of the reason it has such replayability.Besides the free content there is also 3 versions of paid content purchasable from inside the client. The Basic Edition for $19.99, the first expansion Attack of the Artifacts for $12.99 and the most recent expansion Expedition to the Sky Citadel, also $12.99. Each of these packs adds new campaigns, new items (which means new cards), new enemies, and new costumes. In the newest expansion, Expedition to the Sky Citadel, your campaign is against the GM - Cardotron 2000. Adding content from levels 18-21 and also proving you with a level appropriate party in the event you are not level 18. This content is hard, at least the first of the six treasure hunts was. In my first attempt at it I lost several times. Hopefully I can get some more loot and try going at it again. I know this is getting lengthy but there is also a well integrated multiplayer portion to Card Hunter. With ranked leaderboards, custom multiplayer maps and a separate load out for your party. You can play individual ranked games to prove your worth or join a ranked league where you play a set number of games in a certain period of time for rewards. The multiplayer seems balanced, although I haven't played enough of it to be 100% sure.Overall, For a free to play game it can go one of two ways. Lot's of content locked behind paywalls, which make the game feel pay to win. Or a ton of content for free with paid options to progress faster. Luckily they went for the latter. It's always a plus when a free game goes that route, giving you plenty to do and then entices with new content to make you to want to support the game. Card Hunter brings a free, fun and unique card game/rpg to you and presents it in such a charming way.


YouTube™ Video: Card Hunter Intro First Look 

			Views: 36		

			Card Hunter is available for free on Steam now - http://store.steampowered.com/app/293260/ This is the first of 3 videos showcases the early parts of the game.

number of helpful: 12 of 14 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
												Do you like Card Games? Have you ever spent hours upon hours playing D&D along with friends? Then stop reading here, Card Hunter is the game for you!Card Hunter smartly mashes elements of both Collectible Card Games and Table-Top games, layering those with colorful characters and lots of humor, making fun of most common tropes about roleplaying. Finally, all of that is sprinkled with a myriad of references to gaming and pop-culture, resulting in a carefully crafted and absolutely charming experience.The Single Player campaign is well put together and satisfying: the lower level adventures serve as a basic tutorial to the most important concepts of the game, easing the player into the ins and outs of an otherwise complex and deep game. As you keep going through the Campaign's story, the game slowly ups the challenge level, so the player is presented with a rewarding experience without feeling too overwhelmed. Wanna know what's best? You can tackle the whole Campaign cooperatively together with up to 2 of your friends and other fellow players, so you're not forced into playing the game on your own even if you don't like PvP.Finally, if you like some good competition, you can jump right into Multiplayer mode and bring-it-on against other players. The MP mode features an automatic Match-Making System, so newer players are pitted against opponents of roughly the same skill level, making ranked matches much fairer.There's a ton to be liked in Card Hunter and, while this certainly isn't a game for everybody, I'd seriously encourage all Steam users into at least giving it a try. The game's free to play, and the devs really do get the f2p model right. Not only can you play the game without ever spending a penny, if so you desire, but you're never faced with artificial pay-walls. Some game content (a few adventures and skins to customize your in-game characters' appearance) is accessible by paying-customers only, but free-players can otherwise access every item and card in the game via regular play alone, no microtransaction needed, minimizing the pay2win issues most similar games suffer from.I'd also like to vouch for the indie developer making the game and the awesome community surrounding it. If you like your games to be frequently updated with bug-fixes and balance-changes, I assure you'll find all of that in Card Hunter. The devs also regularly work on new content to be added along with updates, with a big expansion usually being released once a year. If you try the game out and do like it, I strongly advise you visit the official site and join the forums there, as those are filled with great info and lots of people ready to help and very welcoming towards to new players.

												Game is fun for first 10 hours. Here's my fundamental problem with the game. You have WAAAAY too many items in thsi game. number of helpful: 11 of 13 people (85%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 30, 2016
												Cardhunter is the crazy love child of the 80s boardgame Heroquest and a simple card game.  The name is slightly misleading as there is no card collecting.  Cards are made available through many hundreds of items.  Deck building is done by equipping items to characters like any other D&D inspired game.  But unlike other D&D inspired games, the effectiveness of each item depends on how it synergises with other items.  An item with powerful cards will be balanced by also containing a number of weak cards.  All items are available for free and will drop randomly just by playing the game.  Many of the Steam reviews suggest this game is pay to win.  This is simple not true.  I became a top 10 player without spending a cent*.  I have seen some rich players dropping hundreds of dollars to fast track their item collection.  But you cannot buy any specific items.  So money gives them very little advantage.  Any seasoned player in the world chat will tell you the same.  You must grind your way to the top and this is a good thing.  The match making system makes use of Elo ranking, and will prevent you from playing against an experienced player that will definitely win.  Ignore the negative Steam reviews.  Instead go read the positive reviews on Kongregate - http://www.kongregate.com/games/bluemanchu/card-hunter/comments?sort=best*After a thousand hours of gameplay I did purchase content, but only to support the developers.

												Summary: Fun at first, I recommend palying it for a little while, but you will soon get bored. The prices are too steep, so don't buy anything, it won't be worth it. They missed too many simple things to warrant asking for purchases.Its fun at first when you play with friends but the grind is real. The prices are a little too steep for me for the what you get. The game missed alot of simple things that would help, such as  tile labeling for communicating with friends. The blocking cards on the AI are pretty OP, they roll a block at least 60% of the time and usually have 3 or 4 of them while none of mine really ever blocked. You reach dead ends that you have to grind 5 or 6 times before you can progress, which is around the 7-10 lvls. I havent gotten past lvling my group to 11, because I get too bored. I recommend downloading it for a quick go to game, but once you get into it a ways in you will get bored. If you buy any of the in game transactions you really wasted money. I could've seen myself spending $5 back when I thought the game was fun, but $20? LOL. I'm glad I don't have buyers remorse. I want to get to the higher levels featured in the screenshot, but theres absolutely nothing that will keep me playing this game for that long. The grind is WAY to grueling.A year later I remembered this game and picked it up again, they seem to have fixed the unfair rolling tables. I still find their prices extremely laughable. Plus for all the 'is it pay to win' confusion, it's a 'pay to not grind' so you get things much more quickly. All who find this not helpful are those that paid $100 and are salty about it lol

content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
												I really want to like this game. I do. But I've hit a point where all I can do is repeat a handful of vexing missions against what seems like ridiculous odds and can't seem to advance anymore. I am glad I only put a little bit of money into it because I think I'm done with it. As an example, I am a full level above one of the Treasure Hunt missions but cannot make any headway- the enemies have an endless deck of huge area effects that generate difficult terrain and they themselves have Hover. It gives a hint- to get robes that have Hover! Well, that's great, but I don't have any and at the time, there wasn't any in the stores that I could find, either. On top of that, it only means my squishy Mage gets Hover, since that effect only comes in robes, and then only if I happen to get that card at some point during the battle while the mage is still alive. I constantly find myself with Warriors that have lots of movement cards but no offense, or lots of offense but no movement. Another Treasure Hunt mission has my characters two full levels above the level requirement and is a capture-the-flag type mission with one victory space. Only the defending monsters are ridiculous, two of them have a seemingly endless supply of poison dart ranged weapons, the other two fly, have twice as many hit points as two of my three characters (and have one-and-a-half times that of my fighter), and a huge melee attack they always seem to have at the ready. If I am lucky with drawing movement cards, I can get within a few spaces of the victory square before my last character dies, or I take a slow approach, keep my characters alive, but lose on points. Twice I actually got a character on the victory space, right before death, and both times by the time I had gotten there, killing that character was the last victory point they needed to win. What else am I supposed to do? There are two missions a level below me I have beaten and two missions a level below me I can't beat (not to mention the level 7 treasure hunt two levels beneath me I also can't beat). Is this it? I really want to like this. I love the old-school-DnD art and tabletop RPG look but the puzzle-nature of the game coupled with needing just the right cards (that you may not even have access to) puts this soundly in the "dislike" category. At least it is essentially free, though I did buy the Basic pack (and am regretting it now). I just can't recommend it.

number of helpful: 14 of 21 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												It's already been 6 hours?Card Hunter is an excellent tactical game in which you play a pen and paper game(Much simplified and game-y-fied of course) where you have a party of 3 heroes in a medieval/fantasy style setting. You go through questing modules and collecting loot to of course upgrade your own equipment and play through the storylines presented.It's a charming game with simple but good graphics, a solid foundation for gameplay, and plenty of quests available. You do not seem to be hampered or stopped by paywalls, which seem to only be there to allow you access to more loot, cosmetics, and at times to unlock some new adventures. Not that you -need- those adventures, you can do just fine without them, but it does seem like it would be a good idea to get them at some point.In game, you will find the movement and combat to be intuitive, with all moves being detailed on cards you play it is easy to look up what something does, and you won't find yourself blindsided by surprise gameplay changes. It's all about knowing your tools and using them well.For the looting fans, you can spend your gold to buy extra loot chests, and for those who love to optimise everything there is a good variety of equipment available that is sure to get you exactly what you need to build your dream team.While it starts a bit slow, it builds up quickly and gets in full swing fast enough to be comfortable without any moments where the difficulty hits you on the head.I haven't even tried the multiplayer yet, but with the solid base this game has, co-op, and ranked play I seriously doubt I would be disappointed.Edit: Checked out multiplayer, am not disappointed.Another edit: Not all is fine with this game. Login queues are a thing, and it seems to be online only. This wouldn't be a problem if they had a 'cancel' or 'quit' button on the queue, but ctrl-alt-del is the only way outAs a summary, Card Hunter is a great tactics game with good atmosphere and as opposed to many 'free' games, this is actually a game you can play for free and enjoy. It is certainly worth giving a try

												Card Hunter is one of those games that look pretty boring and tedious, but once you start to actually play. You get into it and it becomes quite addicting.Pros -Not pay to win at all.-Good flow-Solid battle mechanics-Multi-player -Co-op (you can play along with friends)-No constant grinding for items-Easy to get rare-epic items-Plenty of itemsCons-In the beggining a pretty long queue-Really short and really long battles-Some exclusive items that aren't available without paying for for ex. costumes. Posted: June 4, 2016
												Great game for a free option! I'm new to D&D type games so it took me a bit to get into it, but it's suprisingly addictive. It's easy to learn and there are a few downfalls to the novice out there.PLUS:- Free- Lots of items and frequently win rare/epic items in chests.CONS:- I sometimes feel like I'm always playing above my skill level. Some levels can be incredibly frustrating.- In order to have success, you have to rebuild your deck for each campaign/battle. Luckily the game will provide you with "hints" if you lose a battle.Overall, it has kept my attention for 10 hours so far and I'm not out anything other than time.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2015
												A cute little distraction while you wait for the next big dungeon-crawler to play.If D&D and Magic the Gathering had a child, this would be it.Free to play, with cash options to speed things up, Card Hunter never ceases to challenge, change up enemies so you have to change strategies, and tickle our fancy with culture-references. (I saw zoidburg, the acrobat from the old D&D cartoon, and much more!)PROs:-Fun, grid-based combat wil static D&D minis and flat terrain on a table. Adorable!-Fast-paced, addictive, lovingly-crafted visual appeal.-Correctly balanced for challenge, it never felt unfair.-Enemy AI is more than competant (you CANNOT just charge in)-Use of chokepoints, bridges and terrain is necessary to win, making you feel smarterCONs:-You are at the mercy of the dice and deck you build. It WILL screw you over more often than you feel it should. You WILL be helpless sometimes, eating multiple attacks and spells without any armor cards. You WILL pin bosses in corners and have nothing to hit them with sometimes. You WILL get stuck on acid, spikes, or lava from lack of movement cards. A LOT of this game is left to things out of your hands. Hope you've made your sacrifice to the RNG gods before you boot this game up.

												Nifty Free to Play RPG game using cards as actions and turn based tactical combat.  Does have a multiplayer co-op system and pvp.  It worked, it has Good graphics and artwork that fit the theme, sound, gameplay.  Reminds me of my days of playing Dungeons and Dragons by pencil and paper.  You get the Cards from gear you are wearing, and you get the gear from chests in quests and vendors in-game.  You can play solo vs AI with a party of 3 members that you control fully.   Maybe Enough free material to get you to level 20, then you have to buy the store modules.  Might be a bit grindy.There are modules, pizza (store coin) and membership you can buy with real money. for more info:

(However ingame mod is level-headed enough to not just ban you for stupid reasons like other games.)

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 20, 2015
												There's an excellent film from 2013, called Zero Charisma, which anyone with even the slightest interest in so-called "RPG" gaming should surely watch.  Most of you are liable to HATE it, 'cause it ain't exactly "flattering" to gamers, but like Taxi Driver before it, it's one of those films which allows you to gaze at aspects of yourself unflinchingly in a mirror, and decide which bits you'd like to keep and which bits you maybe, just maybe, should try and change about yourself.      But I'm getting way, WAY too "deep" here, especially for the game I'm about to review.  So let's skip, if we may, to a particular scene in said movie, in which our anti-hero/"gamemaster", named Scott, rants at some poor kid (who wants to join his tabletop gaming group) about the evils of video games which purport to be "role-playing games", when they lack what he believes to be the core ingredient of such games: "Communal storytelling."  Now, whether or not you agree with Scott over how important such things are in the grander scheme of life, there's no denying that no video game ever has had, or ever will have, the "depth" of storytelling and character which a bunch of people sitting around a table with pen, paper and dice can achieve.  No matter how advanced and "clever" computer programs might get, they'll never be able to improvise action or explore characters to the extent which a group of switched-on, imaginative, flesh-and-blood human beings can.      Of course video game "RPGs", however erroneously named, have absolutely no NEED to aspire to such heights, because they have OTHER things going for them.  They're more visual, more aural, more immediate...hell, you don't even need any FRIENDS, 'cause they tend to have single-player options.  Video games have a LOT of things going for them which old-school RPGs don't; just as surely as old-school RPGs have their own strengths when compared to video games.  So what does all this have to do with Card Hunter, the video game I'm allegedly reviewing here?  Well, I could let the devs themselves answer that question for you, but since you're stuck with me, I'll continue putting things in my own words.  But in order to do this, I shall also have to touch upon the "evolution" (or "de-evolution", depending on your point-of-view) of the (in)famous Dungeons & Dragons game.  Sure you've heard of it.  The people who made Card Hunter certainly have...    D&D began as the purest of tabletop "role-playing games"; perhaps even the ORIGINAL of its species, unless I'm mistaken.  But what is even more important to note is that, since its inception in the 70s, D&D has gone through many different permutations (including the ADVANCED D&D, or AD&D, system), and while I've only "seen" and have not actually played more recent editions, the general inclination in recent years has been to make D&D more, I dunno, "accessible" to new audiences I guess, by pushing it in a slightly more "board game"-ish direction.  Card Hunter takes things one step further still by adding even MORE blatant "board game"-y elements, like, well, CARDS (oddly enough, given its title)!  And again, "accessibility" would seem to be a key word in their thinking herein.      They've also proudly played up - as opposed to down! - the "nerdy" aspects of such games, by...well, play the game and you'll see what I mean.  It's not subtle.  As for whether it's "hilarious" or "cute" or "charming", or simply "grating" or downright "insulting"...well, that's up to the individual.  Scott from Zero Charisma certainly wouldn't approve...in fact, he'd probably put his fist through the computer monitor in rage.  But are we all Scott?  Of course not.  Me personally, I'm probably half-way between sympathising with Scott and thinking the dude should chill out a tad and GET A ♥♥♥♥ING LIFE.  Would he at least be right if he were to complain of a lack of storytelling and character in this "RPG"-styled game?  Of course he would.  Card Hunter is, in essence, just a bunch of semi-tactical battles with a bit of buying and selling and character recruiting in between.  It does, however, lovingly "frame" said battles in D&D-styled "modules", which do go some way towards evoking Ye Olde Memories for soon-to-be nursing-home nominees like yours truly.  If you ever played or bought any old-school D&D paraphernalia, boy, are you gonna have flashbacks!  A lot of the titles of the "adventures" are even puns or variations on famous old D&D modules ("Black Plume Mountain", anyone?), and the art style is also frequently spot-on.      So is this, ultimately, a loving "tribute" to, or a♥♥♥♥♥♥take/post-modernist revision of, those old D&D adventures?  Well...it's both, really.  Let me put it this way...you can choose to buy "pizza slices" if the Free-To-Play format gets too sluggish and "grind"-y for your tastes (and you wanna, er, CHEAT, basically).  And there's plenty of other cheeky nods towards gamers and gaming culture itself, as opposed to trying to fully immerse you in a world other than our own.  Actually, the first thing you'll see when you start the game up is a title screen declaring this "The Game Of Fantastical Adventure Limited Only By Your Imagination!"  Which is, of course, a complete and utter crock of♥♥♥♥♥♥♥  Even the likes of the oldest-school D&D were pushing their luck when they made statements like that.  But I'm pretty confident that the Card Hunter devs KNOW this, and I'm more than happy to nod appreciatively at their constant and well-meant in-referencing.  Having said all that...do I LOVE this game, given that I believe that I understand precisely what it was "meant" to be?Well..."love" is certainly a strong word.  I certainly like it, quite a lot.  But I've only played a bit over an hour, gotten one measly achievement, and for now I might just put it aside and come back to it when I'm a bit more in the mood (or after I've finished playing Darkest Dungeon, a game more defiantly up my alley).  But it's all up to the individual really, and your own individual sensibilities, and as long as you avoid the lure of the Pay-To-Win incentives, it's a pretty impressive game for the big fat sum of ZERO DOLLARS and ZERO CENTS.  It's fun, has a gob-smackingly beautiful visual aesthetic, inventive sound...there's absolutely no denying that it's a high quality game within the parameters it sets for itself.  But please, please, for the love of the Gods, and this is mostly aimed at all you ♥♥♥♥ing KIDS (under thirty) out there...pretty, pretty PLEASE don't think that this is what a "role-playing game" is.  No video game will EVER replace those, as they're actually about more than just statistics and combat and random number generation.  They really are (at least at their best).  Think of this more as a compromise between, say, super-simplified D&D and Talisman (the board game).  Or failing that, let's just call it a VIDEO GAME with light "strategy" elements and light "RPG" elements, and we can all just stay friends, whad'ya say?For now I'm done, but I'm sure I'll return to it in time, when I'm in the mood for a grind-y dungeon hack-er with meticulously "cheesy" aesthetics.  (Hey, come to think of it...maybe the "pizza" symbolism they came up with was pretty apt after all!?)  The game is free, doesn't take up much disc space, and in all honesty you may as well download it and give it a go if you've bothered to even OPEN this Steam Store page.  So why are you sitting there, reading this appallingly long and tiresome review?  Quick, before someone thinks you're a NERD, 'cause you like to READ 'n'♥♥♥♥♥♥..PLAY THE ♥♥♥♥ING GAME!  You don't want people to think you're "smart" or some♥♥♥♥♥♥like that, do ya?!?  Verdict: 8/10.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
From Blue Manchu comes the simple and fun free-to-play turn-based strategy game, Card Hunter. This Dungeons and Dragons-themed title melds customizable characters and roles with a combat systems that can be learned with very little play time. There are little-to-know pay-to-win features, utilizing the in-game currency (pizzas) for mostly cosmetic character items; pizzas can also be earned at certain points of the game, and players should not find it truly necessary to purchase theses pizzas unless they wish to support the developers in this admittedly fun title. This game can be quite humorous, and the dialogue and text can be quite interesting, so that is another plus.Here are just a few reasons to Roll for Initiative in Card Hunter:Gameplay - Card Hunter utilizes a grid in which to structure battles. Depending on which stage the characters find themselves in, hostile figures, obstacles, and backdrops will differ from previous encounters. There-in lies a question directed from new or potential players: what determines the actions player characters can make? Each character-individual forces when enemy non-player hostiles are involved- has their own deck of cards which define specific actions, maneuvers, and attacks that specific figure can perform. Once a player performs an action with a character, the enemy does so, and so on; these phases of actions continue until both sides pass their turns consecutively, in which both forces must discard cards until each individual figure has, at most, two cards each. This mechanic was likely implemented to entice players to commit to actions while not hoarding cards for later turns in a battle. The main objective, however, is to eliminate the opposing force by reducing each of their figure’s health to zero or below, or by other means described in scenarios within a campaign. There are also multiple races-humans, dwarves, and elves-in which players can add in any combination to their party, as well as varying classes that can be assigned to them.Items - You may have heard mentions cards and asked yourself, “Why is this not a card game? Why is this portrayed mostly as a grid-based strategy game throughout this review?” To answer these questions, Card Hunter does feature cards that dictate actions and a maneuverable gird to which to strategize, but cards are obtained much differently than in traditional trading card games. In-game items are given to players after each battle as loot and there are varying slots in which they can be assigned; they also retained individual rarities and levels so that players can grade and compare cards that can be placed in similar slots on the player’s characters.Character Leveling - As players complete adventure paths, their individual characters gain experience which boosts health points and possibly opens up item slots that allow characters to expand the card count and variability in their decks. For example, at level five my dwarven fighter now has the capacity to equip three weapons, as well as a martial skill and other helpful items which grant bonus cards and traits. Though leveling is a somewhat slow process, this is compensated by the abundance of quests that are granted to the player upon completing others; these quests also have a daily reset allowing players to complete them only once daily, but so many quests open up at once that this hardly presents an issue-after three hours of play I found no need to revisit on of my previously completed quests.Theme - Card Hunter is a pretty blatant Dungeons and Dragons-themed title. The game’s Dungeon Master is named Gary after the legendary Gary Gygax, dice rolls are mentioned frequently in accordance to mechanics within the original roleplaying game, each adventure path’s synopsis and art is based on classic modules; it is fairly obvious yet awesome.TL:DR - Card Hunter has a few features that could possibly mark it as a ‘fee-to-pay’ title, but after five hours of total play I have not utilized nor have I felt it necessary to utilize the paid functions of the game. This title is extremely fun, though I have not yet had the opportunity to experience either cooperative or player-versus-player online features; I cannot accept nor deny the credibility of the online community. Card Hunteris recommended for those who enjoy card- or grid-based strategy game. Also, if there are any new or existing players who would like to play cooperatively but do not know anyone else who plays, I would gladly join in. Thanks for reading.Do you enjoy these reviews? Please visit my Curator Page at  Spearpoint Reviews	.

												Despite what a lot of people might say about this game at this point in time, I think it's fairly enjoyable. I decided to start playing it because I wanted something somewhat strategical but not ridiculously difficult or with a lot of depth. I have little to no experience in this game's genre. I found a great balance in this game. I haven't actually played the multiplayer, but the single player (at least in my experience) is more fair than many people seem to be saying it is. However, if you at least want a game you can continually return to and play whenever you're bored I suggest you give Card Hunter a try.

												A very interesting little game.The idea is simple: move your characters around a battle field to fight monsters, complete quests and gain loot. The mechanic is what makes the difference. Each item you equip gives you a number of cards and you play these cards to move, attack, defend and cast spells. There are a variety of quests and a multiplayer mode with both co op and pvp optionsThe game is simple to play but the tactics are actually very complex.Although you can pay for additional quests etc you can have hours of fun for free and even playing pvp or co op, not spending cash does not put you at a disadvantage.A fun game for casual or serious play

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												It's free, it's clever, it's unique, and it's fun. Yes, you should play Card Hunter.Card Hunter does a truly phenomenal job of taking common trappings - turn based tactical combat, old timey D&D, deckbuilding games, Diablo-esque loot 'em ups - while both using their familiarity and also turning them on their heads. In brief: adventuring earns you equipment, each piece of which is represented by a combination of 3 cards that you use to move and act in battle. Leveling up increases your number of (and power of) equipment slots. Add that up, and you have a sneaky deckbuilding game, where each of your three units' decks are assembled with just a handful of actual selections. Combine that with an extensive cast of monsters that each have signature deck strengths, and you've got a thoroughly complex game that comes together pretty intuitively, especially since none of this would actually work with real-world cards.And it bears mentioning separately: the free-to-play elements are extremely subdued. The benefit provided by real money payments notable but far from gamebreaking, and the game avoids the typical problem of desperately showering you in ads.If there's a downside, it's that equipments tend towards side-grades rather than upgrades. While that seems like a positive at first glance, it does eventually mean that you'll be drowning in hundreds of equipment options that, while maybe not equally viable, offer a dizzying array of possibilities. It's an easy game to pick up, but a difficult one to get back into if you've been away for a while.Still, it's not like it'll cost you anything.

number of helpful: 64 of 124 people (52%) found this review helpful68 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
												Buffs1. Lovingly crafted homage to non-digital RPG gaming (PnP, TCG, and board games).2. Satirical story line involving noob GM, Gary and his hardcore older brother, Melvin is nostalgic and funny.3. Tons of free content.4. An editor allows you to create your own battles which can potentially be added to the game.Debuffs1. If even the positive reviews express frustration at the RNG then you know it's a problem. Forget about strategy and deck-building; getting a beneficial draw is so unlikely that I fail even in lucid dreams of the game (which after nearly 300 hours there are many).2. Distribution of the card types attached to equipment is made with neither rhyme nor reason, causing unneccessary limitation and imbalance. Your warrior can choose 1 of 52 different martial attack items which buff everything from bash, chop, and penetrating attacks to bash, chop, and penetrating attacks. Do you like fire? Lucky you; you can load your wizard with 2 staves and 4 arcane items providing fire magic cards to be buffed by your pyrocentric arcane skill. Do you prefer electricity? You can go to hell; there are some nice shocking staves but not a single 1 of over 200 arcane items adds lightning attacks.3. The game has been ensorcelled by dark magic to compel people to keep playing even as they rail against it. Even days after uninstalling I am plagued by images of bludgeon-resistant black oozes whenever I close my eyes.

Posted: September 22, 2015
This game is an isometric , Dungeons and Dragons-esk game. In Card Hunter, you chose a wizard, warrior, and priest.In each adventure, you are left with different foes and map sizes. When you have killed all Monsters or Enemy humans, you open a chest and get loot, each piece of loot (Except for treasure) can be equipped and unlocks certain cards with differentDamages, effects, and qualities. There are also qualities to the items themselves, such as; Common, Uncommon, Rare, Epic, and Legendary. There are many game modes for Card Hunters as well, such as; Campaign, Co-op, Citidel, Treasure Hunter, and others.In conclusion; This was one of my favorite games on Steam, and I highly recommend getting it.

number of helpful: 16 of 30 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												Been a long time Card Hunter fan and I'm glad it is finally coming to Steam! I probably have 1000+ hours in the game if you include the web version.tl;dr: Neat CCG game that is free-to-play and *not* pay-to-win. Extremely fun and unique game with a cool retro feel, but can be overly random, imbalanced, and frustrating at times. If you enjoy CCGs and some light RPG stuff then check it out.Obviously I'm a bit biased (both having played the game since beta and contributed published content), but I really enjoy the game and the unique things it brings to the Collectible Card Game (CCG) based format. Unlike many other CCGs, this game is absolutely NOT pay-to-win. In fact, some of the top rated players have never spent a dime. The content you purchase is really just for cosmetics, extra single player levels, or small boosts to collecting speeds (like 15% boost, which is not much at all). If you enjoy the game you should support it not so you get stuff, but so Blue Manchu can keep making new content.The game is basically a mash up of a CCG with miniatures. You use cards to control the miniatures in an arena combat. Levels will often have interesting challenges that you need to overcome, with unique cards that can drastically change how you need to play. There's a decent amount of depth in when to play what card, when to pass early, and how to manage character facing and position. There's a lot to love, a lot to learn, and a lot to master.While I do love the game, it isn't for everyone. It skins itself as an RPG, but it is much more a deck building / CCG style game. Some single player levels are extremely difficult and require you to rework your party just to overcome the challenges. Don't view it as an RPG where you get your stuff and slowly get better replacement gear -- almost every item has a use in some situation (even the super bad items are useful once you finish the game for Quests). This is both good and bad as it requires you to tailor your builds to the level, but also results in often playing a single player level just to immediately lose due to not having the "right stuff" equipped.Outside of that, my main complaints about the game is that it is a bit too luck based and imbalanced. There is the obvious card drawing element, but then there are dice rolls where a single one can make or break a match. Additionally, there are a few balance problems with some cards being overly dominant. If you're a hardcore CCG fan who wants to create an undefeatable build then the multiplayer game probably isn't for you. Yes, top ranked players are consistently top ranked (I was #1 for quite a while), but that doesn't mean you won't lose matches against bad players just due to sheer dumb luck.Overall, the game is very unique and fun. Since it is free there isn't much cost in trying it out. If you enjoy CCGs and have a nostalgia for old school RPG tropes then this game is perfect. I'd recommend people check it out even if you're on the fence. At most you'll lose a few hours, but at best you'll find a new love like I did.If you have any questions about the game feel free to contact me. Always willing to help out. =)

Posted: February 12, 2016
												I like card games, board games, strategy games, and rpgs. This games has a mix of all my favourite genres. If you have similar likes then this game should appeal to you.Its a free game and I like how the developers have made effort for it not to be a pay to win game. Play through the long campaign.  If you get stuck, visit the shop and buy some cheap common cards/gear and change your strategy. Certain cards work better than others on different maps. I played through the campaign without needing to grind. After that you will unlock quests which are more challenging. You can pay to unlock additional maps but it not necessary to experience the game.Plenty of multiplayer options including ranked matches, co-op and league matches. If you are stuck ask someone to help you out. IF you have poor cards then play a league match with fixed deck. If you want to do well in multiplayer I recommend playing through the campaign first to become familiar with the game mechanics.The more you play, the more you feel like getting some pizza.

Posted: July 31, 2015
												[All of my gameplay has been in the campaign mode. I haven't messed with multiplayer]I admit, this game is pretty fun. It has been fun being able to play with two other friends regularly bringing us together occassionally to laugh and cry with our roleplaying (sometimes erotic roleplaying *wink wink*). I've actually pulled all-nighters on this game because the story itself is so fun. I've taken the freedom to continue leveling by myself to further experience the game. I have to say, this game's difficulty increases as you level. Unfortunately, the AI in Compaign mode can really mess you up in a couple of turns if you don't pay attention to "line of sight" and "playing it safe" a couple of rounds. My biggest complain are the matches with the yellow victory boxes because usually in those matches, you are outnumbered three to five+ and their AI is programmed to always end their turn in the yellow victory boxes. It is a pain sometimes because the monsters also have cards to push you away from the victory boxes. If you're playing Co-Op with one friend, you better be prepared to look for an additional player when dealing with the yellow victory boxes because you will be outnumbered and have a big disadvantage in those matches. Also, the enemy casters like to run away from you so you spend most of that match trying to corner them to melee them. That isn't a big deal compared to the yellow victory boxes though; just not fun when you run two clerics and a warrior (one of the clerics being dwarven) and just running around the game board the whole match getting hurt from ranged attacks.

Posted: August 14, 2015
												If you've ever opend a box of D&D with friends, you'll find a special place for this game. Very nostalgic, very nerdy, and very much perfect. The graphics are appeasing, The game play is intresting and well thought out. Theres so much to like here. F2P with a pizza cash store on the side if you want to speed things up a bit or get some extra cosmetics. Co-op, multi-player, and even the community seems to be helpful. If nothing else give it a try, the game itself is free. There are three "DLC" to open up other game levels/content that you can definately enjoy the game without. The prices range from $19.99 for the basic set which includes 11 quests a month's sub, and several cosmetic items. The other two "DLC's" are $12.99, and have a variety of quests and other goodies. Again, theres nothing you HAVE to buy to enjoy the game, just add on stuff and extra quests.Bottom line, dont pass this up if you like pen and paper table top games. Do your self a favor and get this FREE game and give it a try.

Posted: July 22, 2015
												Loved this game since I played it on Konggregate. I once mentioned to the developer that he should have placed his game on Steam and luckily he told he had plans. To think a tiny developing studio in Australia would create such an interesting game and make it free-to-play. The game ended at Renown 19 for me. That was the max one could go without paying pizza. Everything else must be paid for. Metallic Metropolis is the max free.PROS1. Just like DnDWhile there is no adventure core story, the simple narrative of Gary the DM, his older brother and the Pizza Manchu delivery girl does give an interesting side story.2. SimplicityEasy to learn and play. Pick up a cardboard 3. Multiplayer Co-opJust like DnD. I hope that the reference to DnD is not a negative notion but it's the most traditional frame of reference I can think of. Getting to play with others to complete quests is great.4. Variety of monstersSo far, I have yet to see size Large (4 square),  Huge (9 square) monsters. Perhaps, that could be in Card Hunter 2? Edit: I've seen a 2x2 (4 square) monster already.CONS1. Pay-to-WinI don't like the idea of getting an advantage over another player by paying Pizza (in-game currency) for an increase in the probability of getting better items. The argument that "skill" mitigates this advantage is flawed. E.g. Trying playing a game with the starting items versus someone with all Epics from paying Pizza.I understand that the developer needs to make money but I think it shouldn't be at the expense of the "fun and fariness" of the game.2. No Overaching Quest NarrativeHoping for a game story, not the DM's love interest. I think Cardtron seems interesting. The silly Melvelous (Melvin's in-game character) was fun too. 3. Limit of 3Hoping for a 5-man group. 5 is a great number versus 3. Perhaps, it might be more taxing to control 5 units but the developer could design 3-man quests, 4-man quests, 5-man quests. That way you can have ho-hum levels, medium levels and epic levels. 3-man just doesn't give the same excitement. Perhaps, in Card Hunter 2?4. MechanicsYou should look at a board game called "Descent" by Fantasy Flight Games. Cardhunter might want to incorporate things like activating switches e.g. Instead of the yellow VP square, blue switch squares to activate in-game mechanisms.5. Doors. It is really ridiculous to see doors get knocked back.

Posted: July 15, 2015
												Card Hunter (when it was only a browser game) was easily my game of the year when it came out. Now that it's on steam, and still free, all I can say is, YES. PLAY THIS GAME, my friends.Loot, turn-based tactics, loot, challenges, more loot and some gamey humor. This is Magic the Gathering meets D&D mashed up with chess.  With loot. You don't need to pay to win, but if you like the game it's worth supporting the devs and buying the extra adventures--but in no way necessary to enjoy Loot Hunter. Err, Card Hunter.More seriously, Card Hunter is extremely challenging. You must wield the best cards for the immediate battle, position your party of dungeon delvers carefully, and figure out which enemy monsters must be taken out first. Ultimately when you fail, and we all fail, regroup with your new knowledge of what fizzled and puzzle out how to reach that glorious loot. The tutorial is fantastic, so quit reading and hit that play button.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2015
												So, if you like board games & tabletop, grid based tactics or card games, check out Card Hunter (now on Steam).So far I have put a good chunk of time into it, and this game is a blast.Why?Pros:------1. Free to play.2. Not true pay to win. You can unlock extra missions and treasure hunts with pizza, which is purchased with real cash. There is also gold used for items and chests (which can drop random gear, including the best). They give you enough pizza to unlock quite a bit of the end-game treasure hunts just by playing through the campaign, if you hold onto it. Gear drops from chests at the end of matches, and it's quite random with the loot drops (RNG). Everything can be obtained without a single spent penny.3. Gameplay. Think your traditional grid-based tactics game... with cards. Instead of having set attacks, you draw cards each turn and that is what you have for that round. The cool part is that each character draws cards, and the cards in each characters deck are dependent on what gear you have equipped. Equipment in this game gives you various cards (which are your attacks and skills) instead of traditional stats4. Campaign is a bit entertaining, sometimes repetitive, but good. Once you finish the game, you can redo any mission with special challenges that must be dealt with. These missions give you good loot drops.5. Multiplayer: This game has 2 and 3 player co-op, as well as true 1v1 pvp. 2 player allows for an additional card draw per character to make up for the lack of numbers. It's an absolute blast. There is also true pvp multiplayer, which is ladder/elo based. In this mode, everyone is given 3 characters to use that are higher level (once you unlock them in the campaign), or your own characters once you finish leveling them. You get to use whatever equipment you have found as well. In my opinion, this is the true game. There are so many combinations between all of the gear, character race and class options that you rarely see 2 people of the exact same build.Cons:------RNG. On occasion, it hits you with a left on card draws & defense rolls, and finishes with a big right to the jaw on loot drops.- Boom$t!ck  /WARComm/  - War Gaming Community (check us out for more reviews and giveaways!)┏━━━┓ ┃┏━┓┃ ┃┃╋┗╋━┳━━┳━━┳┓┏┳┓╋┏┓ ┃┃┏━┫┏┫┏┓┃┏┓┃┗┛┃┃╋┃┃ ┃┗┻━┃┃┃┗┛┃┗┛┣┓┏┫┗━┛┃┏┓ ┗━━━┻┛┗━━┻━━┛┗┛┗━┓┏┛┗┛ ╋╋╋╋╋╋╋╋╋╋╋╋╋╋╋┏━┛┃ ╋╋╋╋╋╋╋╋╋╋╋╋╋╋╋┗━━┛
