content:
Posted: May 7, 2016
												Fun, but the game won't allow you to do a co-op game using only one computer (I know that single player you can control all the heroes in your party but it's set up in a way that you couldn't play a multiplayer game with someone in that way). Also, inventory and equipment management is a hassle. There's a bunch of stuff that's labeled as useless and only able to be sold but there's also many different variations of them turning your inventory into a sack full of useless junk. I think it would have been way easier to just have given the player gold directly instead of having them waste time on figuring out whether something is equipment or junk. I digress. The game itself is entertaining so if you can get past the inventory and mulitplayer/co-op issues you should be alright.Oh and microtransactions are shoved in your face... so that's annoying. In a regular game you would fight a boss and get rare or higher rarity loot. Well, in this game instead of getting that loot it's withheld from you and you're asked to pay for it with real money as if the game is giving you this amazing bonus but in fact they just took a slice out of the content (no pun intended)--such a simple game feature at that--and are asking you to pay $$$ for it... then again you could argue that it's a 'free' game... but still, quit shoving your sticky pizza in my face.

												This is an incredibly fun to play take on the good ol' table top dungeon stomping genre.I figured I'd tire of it, but I find myself heading back to it every couple of weeks, playing a few levels, and quitting with a sense of satisfaction.Mechanics are card-based rather than dice-based, with your deck changing based on your equipment. content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												When the only negative review on a game is "I can't get in because there's too much people trying to play" It says it all... I don't know how you can review a game based on not playing it. But I did play and it's awesome. COOP CAMPAIGN!!!! This game is a mixed between old school dungeons and dragons and Magic the gathering. The CCG part is pretty simple but it contributes to a very good strategy board game. Sadly there's only 3 classes and 3 races but there's so much card possibilities that you can make your cleric a "Warcleric" or your fighter a quick moving assassin. Oh and the free to play model IS AWESOME. No Pay To Win in a CCG is almost unheard of.Warmly recommand the game to anyone really. it's fun easy to understand yet hard to master. Lots of options for multiplayer pvp, pve. You can make the whole single player campaign without paying but if you do you get cool unique weapon (Not stronger just unique). And there's an option to pay for expansions and more quests. my rating 8.5/10 IGN Rating (11/10) yep better than GTA5.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												I've played this game for ~2 years on and off. It's a game that strikes a good balance between card and board game. Needless to say I enjoy it.It is also one of the few F2P games that I have thrown money at because I was enjoying it. Their F2P structure is quite fair. Most of it revolves around cosmetics which are really only for the cool factor. There is a subscription option that you can take for as much as 30+ days or as little as a week. Which really only gets you a piece of bonus loot at the end of a quest. Most of the times that bonus loot is OK but not mindblowing, so it isn't as if they are trying to bait loot you into subscribing. There are also Treasure Hunt maps that have a guarenteed one time drop when you first complete them. That one time drop will also show up as RNG loot throughout the game (quest level permitting) as well as cycling through the merchant shops for in game gold. I've also personally never been huge on most of the Treasure Hunt loot, I have personally fount it to be mostly OK but I seldom if ever use it. The Treasure Hunts for me are mostly for the fun of the quest.tl;dr, the F2p aspects of this game are in no way pay to win and don't feel forced.The PvP is even fairly fun, assuming you dont run into the flavor of the month team or have built a deck to counter said build. Ususally seems to be three dward wizards. I've found myself physically kringing when I load into a PvP match against them but there is something especially satisfying when you emerge victorious or better yet make them rage quit because your deck is set up to be viable vs other builds but almost completely shut them down.  PvP also has a pretty good reward chain. At least for the first 6 chests after which it really depends on if you are still having a good day or not.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
												In short, this game is awesome.There is something of almost everything in it: RPG, turn based strategy, PvE-Campain, PvP-leagues, Co-op and collectibles thrown into a FREE game, which for once does not ♥♥♥♥ up one or multiple elements of the game to the point of annoyance, but not just keeps it all together, but does well so, which is just incredibly awesome.If someone told me about this, i'd probably be sceptical myself, that it's not just working, but working so well.So far you can combine 3 classes with 3 races to form a group of 3 members to go adventuring/ battling monsters, which seems ok at first, not a lot maybe, but as the game progresses it becomes clear, that this rather simple template provides enourmous custumization through the collectible items, which don't grant the usual stat improvements, but provide you with various combinations of action cards, which you can use during combat, making for almost infinite combinations and various stratigies to play with.And while the game introduces you in an o.k. pace, soon it'll test what you've learned, by mixing up settings, introducing combinations of big baddies, swarming you with little critters, or introducing something special every now and then, so you have to adabt your strategies, which not only keeps the game challenging and pushes you to steadily improve, but because of the collectibles and group system, also maintains replay value of already completed levels for the more enthusiastic player.The gameplay is solid, the whole theme is a quirky, fitting homage to classical tabletop- and P&P-RPGs and while the stories are negligible, they often provide a funny background.And last but not least, it actually is free to play, with reasonable paying options, not just a demo, not pay to win, but you can buy special campaigns, cosmetics, or an extra (random) item to loot after each battle, which shouldn't give anyone an unfair edge, but actually makes them good choices to potentially reward the developers, if you like the game enough.As the idea to play those classical RPGs with some of my friends seems to nerdy for them and my attempts to convince them with selfmade moduls failed, this transformation to the digital medium seems like a small dream come true to me.For anyone who might be interested in any of these aspects, i say "happy card hunting"!

content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												Card hunter is a very interesting mixture of CCG gameplay with Tabletop RPG mechanics and an intentionally goofy plot that moves the player through its campaign. I started playing this game two years ago, going through the campaign on my own, having a blast customizing my deck to combat the various enemies the game throws at you while laughing at the tongue-in-cheek dialogue. After that, there was a whole other world to explore in competitive multiplayer with other players, with a system that matches the player up with opponents of a roughly equal skill level. Now with the recent expansion, there's also the possibility to go through the campaign cooperatively with up to two friends, or team up to play a multiplayer match against another team. There's something new to keep you coming back to the game every day, such as special loot rewards for beating certain adventures or 10-hourly leagues which offer completely new scenarios to strategize in.The variety of cards is absolutely huge, there's enough possible playstyles to accommodate anyone's tastes, and the constant collecting of new items and cards means you'll often find ways to adjust your characters to be even more to your liking.Card Hunter is easily the best Free-to-Play game I've ever played with the richest and fullest experience without buying any in-game currency. It's basically as far from a pay-to-win model a Free-to-Play game can be.Anyone, whether they have a casual or deep interest in the game, whether they prefer playing competitively, cooperatively or solo, whether they buy the in-game currency or not can enjoy this game!

												A mashup of collectible card games with D&D, plus a healthy dose of humorous nostalgia.  It's got an adorable art style, constantly shifting tactical combat, and a wonderful community.It's also Free-to-Play, but not in a bad way.  You could play through almost the entire game without spending anything, but you can pay for a set of *even more* adventures (~20 more on top of the 50-odd free ones), get a slight boost in the number of items that drop, or go for excellent cosmetic upgrades.It's the bestest!

content:
Posted: July 20, 2015
In a NutshellCard Hunter plays like a clever tactical board game with a good dose of geek humor that D&D players may especially appreciate. Best of all, it's free, and its microtransactions aren't necessary to win the game.GameplayIf Dungeons & Dragons were played as a board game with decks of cards to resolve combat, the result would be Card Hunter. The gear that your characters equip determine what cards go in their deck. At the start of each encounter, your party of characters and their enemies are deployed on the board, and each of them is given a hand of cards from their deck. The player and the Game Master alternate playing a card from their hands to move across the board, execute a melee attack, or cast spells. When both of them pass without playing any card, the turn ends. If there are any hands with more than two cards, these must be discarded down to two, and two new cards are drawn from their respective decks to form a new set of hands. Play continues until the player or the Game Master attains their victory condition.There is no perma-death in this game, so even if your entire party gets killed, you can always start over with the same party if you want to.My EvaluationUsing cards instead of dice to resolve actions is nothing short of brilliant. This game mechanic adds a level of planning that would not be possible with dice alone. If you enjoy turn-based tactical combat in a D&D-like setting, Card Hunter may be for you. This game doesn't come with an emotionally engaging story (not that you should expect one), but you may appreciate the geek humor that this game has in spades.Note that Card Hunter has microtransactions, but they really aren't necessary to win. Over all, I find the developer's business model to be fair and well worth supporting.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2015
												Welcome, bold adventurer! Card Hunter is an online collectible card game which blends together card play, deck building, tactical combat and fantasy role-playing in a way you've never seen before. Grab your cards, miniatures, dice and snacks, then journey to a new world of adventure on the tabletop of your Game Master, Gary. Build your party and set forth on a grand adventure in the massive single-player campaign. Each adventure will challenge your deck-building skills and tactical prowess as you battle horrifying Black Oozes, savage War Monkeys and more. Amass a collection of fantastical swords, shields and other adventuring gear. In Card Hunter's unique deck building system, equipping your party with these items builds your deck for you. Enter the fray on a grid based battlefield. Prepare for turn-based strategy where you must play your cards right to defeat your foes and be rewarded with experience and loot. When you’re ready, challenge other players in casual games, ranked matches or regularly scheduled leagues. Can you rise to the top of this month’s season? Can you and your undead minions triumph in the Graveyard Gambol league? Multiplayer Card Hunter is a never-ending challenge. Don't want to face the monsters alone? Adventure co-operatively with one or two friends and share the dangers of Cardhuntria as well as the rewards. When you're done with the huge core campaign, get ready for when robots and insane computers invade in the all new Expedition to the Sky Citadel set. Or, if you prefer your monsters from the murky mists of time, brave the challenge of prehistoric monsters and intelligent weapons in the fiendish Attack of the Artifacts.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 21, 2015
												Have you grown older and miss the old days of D&D? Are your weekly Pathfinder games not enough for you? Are you having trouble finding a party of adventures to dungeon crawl with you? Look no further cause Card Hunter brings challenging AI and tactical thinking that will keep you entertained for hours, and it's all free to boot.create a party of three of your choice from from the following races and classes:Races: Dwarve, Human, ElfClasses: Warrior, Mage, PriestWhy not level each type that's a combo of 165 parties have at it!Loot is well set up each class gets specific gear the only ones that are in common are the Shield (which both the warrior and priest get) and Boots (whichs everyone gets) not to mention each class and race get special skill slot. The awesome part is gear is how you get your cards. You don't pick and choose cards individually like a deck builder, but you find loot which have 3 cards attached them them; unless they are weapons which have six cards. The play style for each class is tremindous I can't say on play style is better then the other but there is deffinitely synergy to make a character awesome. Personally I'm thinking of making a life steal dwarven priest, a dwarven mage that plays keep away with a card that causes them to take damage whenever they move and a elven warrior that is hasty to get in close and deal some heavy damage. What type of class you play may fall to lady luck depending on the items your able to find.I have yet to touch multiplayer I want to finish the single player first before I try it out, but single player and multiplayer is linked so that you use the same character and gear and levels are locked when you switch to multiplayer to create an even playing field.Long story short if your a fan of table top RPG adventures this is the game for you.

												It is an enjoyable game that explores the elements of the usual RPG and presents that in a style that anyone could enjoy. There are slow loading times but the gameplay makes up for it. However, the reason why I enjoy this card game over others is that it has character which makes me feel motivated as I build a stronger relationship with the characters I create and Marvin, who is a character I geniunely feel sorry for him as he is constantly being intimidated by his brother. With other games, you are given your cards, play a few games and then leave the game due to a dwindling interest. However, I feel like that this game would be interesting even without the stellar gameplay. Overall, I would recommend this game to anyone who has some time spare as it is a captivting game.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												Remember back in the days where you used to meet up with friends to play tabletop RPG's? This game got pretty close to that feeling, except what is missing is randomness in the story (there is 1 campaign AFAIK) and for me a 4 player co-op instead of a 3 player. Also the fact that the game rolls the dice for you.When I first looked at it in the steam store, I didn't really think that this game (especially that it's free) would give me hours of great fun with friends. Boy was I wrong. After 8 hours of playing with friends and talking to them over teamspeak, we still haven't discovered 1/8 of the map! (it's huge!) There are lots of dungeons and items, ranging from wands or spears to lasers and mines!There is a premium currency in the game called "pizza slices" for which you can get various skins for your characters, weeks of premium (gives you additional loot after every level in a dungeon) or you can buy chests with epic items! At the beginning they give you around $5 worth of the currency, which is enough to open some best chests available for your level and/or buy a skin / week of premium. It's very generous from the developers.Once I launched the game, the tutorial was pretty long, and you had to finish it in order to play co-op or multiplayer. After finishing it, me and my friends chose our characters for co-op and went for an adventure. Another thing missing here is you can't see your friends on the map. It only tells you in the chat where they have moved, and when the team wants to go to a dungeon, the team leader must go there first and press "Battle!". That will invite everyone from the party. It got me confused at first.After that, we really got into the game, we did a 8 hour long session and leveled up our characters to level 7. Then I played some multiplayer, and that is PvP battles on various maps, kind of King of the Hill style.Time for some pros and cons.Pros:- Huge map- Not pay2win- Lots of different equipment and animations.- Multiplayer / Co-op- Lots of joy- Many, many dungeons- A story- Brings back the memoriesCons:- Only 3 player co-op- The game rolls the dice for you (this one is a personal con)- Can't see friends on map when playing co-op- Kind of long tutorial- No randomness in story (the dices thrown by the "GM" (AI) are fixed, unfortunately)- Can't create your own character, no stats (like agility etc.)I can easily recommend this game, especially that it's free, and gives hours of joy and nostalgia. What are you doing? Download it!

content:
Posted: May 13, 2016
Product received for free
												This free game is surprisingly well-developed and fun for many hours.  I love the 1st ed. AD&D aesthetic (done tongue-in-cheek), combined with turn-based party RPG and card-game mechanics.  It's a fun throwback to old Dungeons & Dragons play, but lovingly mocked for its geekiness throughout, and updated for simple but deep tactical gameplay. It's funny without sacrificing any of the actual nerd enjoyment of card-driven fantasy RPG battle tactics.  The perfect audience for this game is someone who loves these sorts of games yet also laughs at the dorks (always dorkier than ourselves, naturally) who played these games in the 1980s.  Beautiful graphics, extremely smooth lag-free play, clear user interface. In-game purchases available but totally non-invasive and inessential to success.  Worth $20, but the developers seem to be banking on the in-game purchases to make up for the excellent development.  No skimping here!

content:
Posted: July 21, 2015
												This is a unique game to say the least, not because of the gameplay, but because of the idea. You are playing a tabletop role-playing game with a Game Master, and you control your minifigures and defeat enemy encounters by using skill cards. Anyway, lets just go on ahead to the pros and cons...Pros-The Concept itself is very cool, I being a Game Master myself. Thank you developers for making a game where the Game Master is actually somewhat relevant :-)Graphically it is good, if you like these cheesy kinda graphics. It just makes it more unique in my opinion.Lots of room for development. The developers will likely add a ton of content over time, which is really cool. Plus you can easily change whatever you want material wise. Want Legend Of Zelda themed pieces? Just change out some of the files and you have it!Cons-Combat, the combat itself is basic, and to similar to basically any other turn/card based games.Costly, the extra content costs quite a bit, but I think the developers have earned it to some degree. Pay-To-Win elements when it comes to the multiplayer aspect of the game.Conclusion-Overall I find this game to be fun. There are some aspects of it that I believe could be changed, but this is a solid game as is and I recommend it. Bring your tabletop roleplaying to the PC using Card Hunter!May your adventures be many and always end in reward!-Donoknight, Founder of Tabletop RPG Gamers League

												Just experienced the game after it's launch in steam, it's a shame that we have to wait so long for it. I've played the game hundreds of hours before it comes to steam, it combines many features which are common in boardgame and ccg, if u play through the single-player part to the pvp mode, u can find more which seems trivia but actually gives more score to the game. Here's some obvious features u can experience even as a new player:1. Tons of collective cards which u can combine them with different strategies in game.2. Never feel boring and always being shocked by some new ideas or play-style in pve, especially pvp.3. Randomess and even some rpg- style makes the boardgame quite unique.4. Friendly community and interesting story plus nice pic and sound systems.5. Great dev. team always add some new things to the game and try to make it's a better world.There're more about the game, but that wait's u to find out. The game itself has a steep learning curve, one needs to learn lots to master the game system. However, in my opinion, I hope to see the game system much more complicated and more elements which can freely utilize in future. If u haven't try this, don't hesitate, it's free anyway.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												Card Hunter takes everything I like about turn-based RPG combat and makes it sing a glorious duet with the infinite combinatorial grace of a well designed collectible card game.  There is a MASSIVE amount of single player content for free, and the challenges (which reward rare loot for replaying each mission) completely alter the way you have to think, relative to your first time through. The  multiplayer, which I swore I'd never touch at first - sucked me in for months. The fiction is best thought of as a cute gift wrapper for the game design, but honestly - it doesn't need more. Finally, it just feels *patient*. You can feel like  you've made progress with only 20 minutes at a time, if you like, or binge for hours. A couple of years ago, as a new father with free time at weird hours, Card Hunter was a kind of refuge of clarity and safety-within-risk. But that was just MY reason to fall in love with it. Stop reading this. Find your own!

												Solid table top/TCG/RPG hybrid8.5/10My biggest grip is the title is a misnomer you don't hunt for cards, you grind against the rng for items that have cards attached to them permanently.Pros-Table-Top/TCG/RPG/Strategy/Turn-based all rolled into one neat little 190 MB package-Addictive-Lots of loot-Challenging campaign with semi-funny npc convos-Reading the text prior to battle gives you a sense of the dev's love for D&D (lots of references in npc convos)-Good music and visuals for what it is-Easy to learn-Multiplayer with leaderboards and tourneysCons-While not altogether not P2W since most items you will use can be found through battles.  There are some features that can be accessed solely through purchasing additional in-game currency, namely the treasure dungeons in the campaign (11 total) and some cosmetic features-needs more cowbell

content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												Having played quite a bit of Card Hunter in my browser, it seemed fitting for me to play it through Steam, because it's a game that's worth sharing.  It's a tactical RPG that's not quite like anything else I've seen.  Rather than your available actions being dictated directly by your characters' classes and equipment, Card Hunter deals you actions from a deck of cards, he contents of which are derived from your characters' gear.  An axe might give you strong, close-range attacks, while a spear gives you weaker attacks with longer ranges.  Armor gives you cards that reduce damage from incoming attacks.  Mages and Priests likewise derive their spell cards from their gear.This opens up a whole mess of options.  Do you go for strength or reach?  Do you use items that offer reliable skills, or those with powerful abilities counteracted by the occasional disadvantage?  Do you forgo a stronger set of attacks in favor of some that have synergy with your other cards?While luck plays a role in the game, it's mostly your deck-building and tactical skills that will determine your success.  It's a well-designed game that offers a lot of options and possible strategies.  It also has numerous unsubtle references for long-time fans of tabletop roleplaying, but these are hardly necessary to enjoy the game.  Ultimately, Card Hunter offers a fresh, rewarding, and just plain fun experience.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												Practically dripping with unique style. This slightly Dungeons and Dragons inspired table top simulator is bound to wrap you up in hours of retro slicing and dicing. And I do mean DICE-ing. If you are a fan of games like D&D, you will love this title not only for it's similarity to those old games but also for it's own personal spin on the genre. I was expecting this game to be pay to win but it's not. Far from it. There is an option to use micro transactions to purchase "pizza slices" which act as gems, crowns, diamonds, etc. do in other games. You use the pizza to purchase what can be summed up as a randomized loot chest which will give you a neat little item but never too far out of your characters level. You can also join a fan club of sorts so that every day you get one more loot item after every battle that is always AT THE VERY LEAST as valuable as the most valuable item you oculd have gotten from that match at your level.This game is amazing and oozing content and style. Download it. It's free. If I could thank the creators personaly, I would.

												This has the potential to be a really great game. But if you do not want to spend money or grind old dungeons over and over for small rewards just to progress at later levels good luck. Higher level dungeons where you are at same item level as the dungeons or slightly below it all comes down to rng which kills the game. Whoever hits their armor rolls will win in battles making the game fustrating when you have to either grind to get over geared and over leveled to pass. Or spend money just so you do not have to keep praying to the RNG gods that the enemies always hit their armor roles and you never hit your armor roles. It truely kills a great game when it comes down to RNG later in the game if you are going the free to play route.

number of helpful: 9 of 19 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2015
												if you go into it like I did, as a casual gamer, you will enjoy the game for multiple hours.  That being said, some of the campaign progression is slowed to have to grind for items to equip your characters with.  This is where a minor pay to progress aspect comes in, but again, it is minor.  This is because you can essentially grind past that either by switching over to multiplayer for a handful of games for better item drops, or repeat previous adventures for  gold to buy better items.  There are reports that at higher levels the game slows even more, but I'm only at level 7 currently after about 8 hours of game play. Item prices in the shops are a little steep and just reflects on a pay to progress (more quickly) model.  I wish there was a better tutorial for new players, but it only took me a few games to get the hang of it. The game provides a new element to card game play by providing the boardgame, so it is a nice mesh between card dueling and boardgaming.The game has been losing players steadily and is currently only at 25% of its average players online at a given time compared to what it had when it released, only 6 months go, in July 2015. (per steamcharts).  Having that large of a drop over that short of a time should be an indication of the game's longevity.I would give this game a thumbs up because there is a good number of hours were it will provide enjoyment.  That being said, there is a lot going against it as far as mechanics go.  The random number generator style of card play can be frustrating.  Selling items is a joke as there is no difference in gp value for a level 1 item, or a level 18 item.  Pay to progress models frustrated me because you either have to choose to grind for hours, or pay real money to get the items faster.  It also seems the developers are not interested in keeping players by ignoring any criticisms that have been made.  This game could have been great if the developers balanced game play, improved their mechanics, and didnt require players to grind for advancement.  There are plenty of ways to incentivise purchases but pay to progress, and pay to win for multiplayer, are the least player friendly ways to go about it.

Posted: July 16, 2015
												I played this game a few years ago on a browser. It was an excellent game to play during community college lectures. However as I got deeper into the story the writing started using heavy handed sexist tropes and I lost a taste for the game. Maybe if I pushed through those issues would have resolved themseves (since this game tries to be self-aware and meta). That said, Card Hunter is still a pretty stimulating game so if you can stomach the male geek humor I definitely recommend it.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												This game is not your average free-to-play. It is an extremely impressive game and will surprise you with just how good it is over and over. I kept being surprised by new elements, like the PVP and Co-op. User-conceived content. Truly enjoyable storyline and even relatively tolerable fluff (for rehashed fantasy RPG stories). There's even a lot of really interesting unique story concepts and some really funny parodies too, if you're a tabletop gamer.I was just overall impressed with this. Unlike other games I play all day at work, I play this all night at home too. I happily forked out some cash to the devs. Tons and tons of quality time I've gotten playing this. And rarely am I inspired to write a review.

Posted: October 25, 2015
												TL DR: Try this game, you will definitely enjoy it and it really is totally free. Humorous, intelligent, intricate and full of references this is a must play for anyone into games set in a fantasy realm.I couldn't recommend this game higher. The game really is absolutely free, not pay to win at all and you could play the entire game without even knowing there was the option to pay for anything extra. Unlike many other game developers there is no in your face obnoxious pressure to pay or subscribe or anything like that. In the end I ended up paying some real money into the game after completing the campaign because I feel like this is an excellent game that the developers deserve to be rewarded for.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												Card Hunter is a deeply enjoyable game. It's a fusion of traditional Dungeons & Dragons tabletop and Magic: the Gathering style card game presented in a charming aesthetic that mimics classic D&D boards. The mechanics, while odd at first are quick to learn and work very well. There's a full suite of some 30 multi-mission adventures on offer, along with fleshed-out PvP that's accessible basically right off the bat in a competitive state.Oh, and all of this is free. Not bad, right?BUT - and this is a very big BUT - the amount of RNG involved in the gameplay is absolutely through the roof. Each character you control draws every move (up to and including actual moving) from an unseen, randomly shuffled deck of cards. The only guaranteed draw is the basic movement card which is always given to you at the start of each round. Absolutely everything else from attacks to healing spells to self debuff cards is completely random.It is maddening and sadly all too common for my fighter (big chap who hits things with a sword/club/lightsaber) to go several rounds in a row without drawing a single attack card, and then draw a single kind of crap one before going another round without. For a class that's supposed to be up close and personal at all times this is downright deadly, especially since in the campaign adventures monsters seem to have an incredibly strong chance of drawing their most potent attack more or less every turn. This also applies to the priest (healing and buff/debuff support) and mage (killing things from far away), who are also both often caught without anything useful in their hands in the heat of the action.Don't get me wrong, Card Hunter *is* a good game. The positives definitely outweigh the negatives by a fair margin. But I cannot stress enough that it can sometimes be an incredibly frustrating experience because so much of it is left down to the whims of RNJesus. The only thing you have complete control over is the positioning of your characters. Play it, but be very aware of that fact because it WILL bite you in the♥♥♥♥♥♥with alarming frequency.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												Disclaimer: I've received in-game premium currency for playtesting and creating custom maps.Card Hunter is a free-to-play hybrid of collectible card game and turnbased strategy pretending to be a tapletop RPG. It has SP and MP modes, co-op, daily rewards, and a map editor. The big thing that makes it unique is the fact that you don't own individual cards; instead you're collecting items that contain 3 or 6 cards each. Each of your chars has their own deck created by the items they have equipped (36 cards once all equipment slots are unlocked) which they draw from during battles.Combat involves moving your chars around on a 2D map (handmade, every SP map is unique) made up of several terrain types, but their actions are limited to the cards in their hands. Attacks can have ranges, area of effect, damage over time, buffs, debuffs, or even create special terrain types. Victory is based not just on what cards you have but also your skill in positioning and timing (the order you play your cards or pass).It truly is free-to-play. Every card, item, race, and class is available for free. The only premium content are special character skins (purely decorative) and certain SP modules that give a specific item when you first complete them. But those items aren't the rarest or best in the game, and can be obtained from random drops and shops in both modes. The other main use of premium currency is Club Membership which gives an extra item every time you win a battle while a member. You can also use the premium currency to buy chests (booster packs) or convert to common curency for the shops, but those are considered to be wastes of money. There is no trading or direct purchasing of specific items you want, you have to wait for it to show up in a chest or shop.Why do I love this game so much? Why have I played it every day for over two years?1. Free. Singleplayer. Turnbased. You just can't find many games that fit all three conditions.2. Nice clear interface. Ben Lee's artwork is beautifully clear and distinctive, making it easy to tell my chars apart. The boards are flat so my chars are never obscured by walls. Lots of useful information when you hover the mouse over things. Ability to mute the music and ambient sounds (they're not bad, I just don't like them in my games).3. SP doesn't force you to play against humans. It's a huge campaign of 73 modules (5 tutorial, 38 regular, 9 fan-made, 21 premium) most containing 3 battles and you can play every single one of them without ever facing a human opponent. (If you'd rather play against humans, at about level 5 you'll be invited to MP and given a free premade party to get you started. Then you'll have to play one more game against the AI to introduce MP rules (timers, draw limits) but after that you can disable AI opponents and play only humans from then on.)

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28, 2016
												Card Hunter has some interesting mechanics worth exploring, all wrapped up in a well-exectued, if well-worn, theme. This is the first game I played blending a card game with a tactical RPG and it does so very well, with your character's deck being based on their gear - which makes it very easy for the RPG fans out there to ease in to the deck-building. Being an RPG fan myself, I can't say that this system does much for the deck-building fans out there, however.Over all, it's a fun romp and worth a couple hours of your time, if just to check out the systems in play. After all, it's free!There are a few microtransactions offered, but none are necessary to progress fully through the game. I can't speak to PVP or Co-Op, as I've only played the Campaign.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2015
												A surprisingly fun little adventure game where you can either play solo with a party of your own characters, engage other players in multi-player colluseum-style matches, or group up with two other players and tackle challenges together. Progression of characters focuses on loot (which gives you different actions) and health, but the game mantains a consistent level of challenge regardless of what echelons you've climbed.In terms of pay-to-play content, it exists, but seems to consist mostly of special adventures (with special loot no doubt) and different models for your characters, but nothing must-have in order to enjoy the general premise of the game.Definitely more fun than I thought it was going to be, and something I have no doubt I'll senselessly pour lot's of time into.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2016
												I have often tried to find a decent PC version of old Pen And Paper games.  I loved playing RPGs as a kid-my older brother would make campaigns for me and my other brother to play, and while I have nobody to play with where I live now the desire to relive the fun is strong.  Card Hunter is the closest game I have found so far to capturing the paper RPG style I am looking for, even with the card game features.  It is fun, and once you start playing it keeps you wanting to play even when you know you should be doing something else.  Best of all, it is free!  I would recomend this to other people looking for an old school RPG experience, especially if you don't have the dosh to by a more complicated game.

												I wrote a review before but I sort of half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥it due to limited time, now that I've played it for a while I want to offer a fuller review:If DnD and MtG had a kid, this game would be it. It's a very interesting board game style game that relies on cards for movement and attacking. It's even portrayed by the characters as being a form of DnD. During the game you will come acrossed equipment for your characters, that have anywhere between 3-6 cards for your deck attached. This peticular mechanic I find unique and the primary reason that it feels like a hybrid of DnD and MtG.The mechanics are not hard, the tutorial is very short and lets you grab the reigns and get your feet wet early without leaving you in the dark. The difficulty raises as you grow in a moderate way, not too hard but not too easy. The pvp can be tedious if you are achievement hunting since things can get really difficult sometimes starting at about a ranking of 850. I haven't tried Co-ops yet but from what little I've seen it's not what I was thinking it is, might be best just to see for yourself. There is a "premium service" and it's not cheap, but it's also about 80% cosmetical anyways, the only practical thing you get from it being the extra rare item that comes from the normal campaign matches as well as access to the treaure hunter campaigns. The only other downer is that even in single player campaign, you are required to have an internet connection just to play, a stable one at least. It seems a little bizarre but I won't ask too many questions about it.So to sum it up, here's my TL;DR version:Pros:- Short and sweet to the point tutorial- Unique and easy game mechanics- Doesn't get terribly boring right out of the gate.- Challenging within reason- Campaign can pause if you need to close the game before or after matches- An actual story exists in Campaign ModeCons:- Premium service is expensive and might be interpretted as pay-to-win- Achievement hunting can be tedious in pvp mode- Whole game cannot work without a stable internet connection, even in Single Player CampaignAfter a while this game might get grindy so for roughly a week, it's a game to fall back to if you're bored. I recommend giving this a try at least.

Posted: January 30, 2016
												I absolutely hate this marinara stain on the white t shirt of gaming. This game revolts me to the highest degree. This game is worse than slavery. This game did 9/11. The die rolls are rigged, the AI will get a 6 three times in a row, and I can't even roll a 3. I wake up in the middle of the night with a cold sweat, vividly remembering that this game still exists on this gay, gay earth. This is the kind of game Oprah warns your mom about.  This is the kind of game that Hitler would have loved. This is the kind of game that thought Prohibition was a good idea. This is the kind of game that screws you left and right, forcing you to pay. This game is like the  fat ginger kid that stole your legos even though he has more legos than you. Just draw some characters on napkins and break your fingers with a hammer, it's cheaper and more fun. This game is the awesomenauts of awesomenauts. Lord help us all.

												Just started getting into it, and this game is awesome. Not pay to win it would seem, though you can advance faster with real money by getting more loot. number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												I just played this game for 4.2 hours straight.It's honestly one of the few FTP games I've played that really feels free to play.You can pay money to buy pizzas which unlock more content and allow you to purchase gold or cosmetic "costumes" for your party. I haven't bought a single thing yet and I've managed to play through tons of content, it feels like the in-game purchases don't affect your play experience in anyway, but it's a nice option to have if you want to boost your experience even further.It plays like an old school RPG game but with cards. You have a party of three that you can upgrade through items that give you additional and more powerful cards in the character's deck, each card gives you different tactics to use in regards to different battles so you will be switching items out according to the scenario.Pros:+Lots of things to do and collect even without dropping any money+Lots of in game content and small jokes which make the experience enjoyable+Wonderful and simple game mechanics+Strategy and variation between tactics of the three characters you controlCons:-I honestly can't think of any at this timeI played this for a little bit back when it was still in development, give it a shot: it's FREE TO PLAY!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												An incredibly well balanced game for old and new players.I've been playing Card Hunter since last year and it continues to impress. Excellent pay model that rewards playing rather than paying (Payment is more geared towards expansions and cosmetics rather than advantages). The deck building is simple but indepth and the community is always on hand to help. Multiplayer is where this game shines. You recieve rewards every time you win and they have multiple leagues daily that contain different maps/creatures/rules on a rotation basis so when you have mastered one a new one pops up. Leagues contain rewards for each participent and increase as you climb the ladder so new loot is always being obtained.

												Having spent so much time reading up on D&D and never actually playing it with friends, seeing this made me smile a little bit. Definitely something worth trying out if you're a fan of card games, but don't consider it P2W because it has microtransactions. With daily adventures and random l00t drops, this is an addictive experience that can only be described as heartbreakingly awesome. Heartbreaking because this was the very first time I ever stumbled onto a card game that was so perfect.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2015
												I still recommend it, but this game does get frustrating as hell after the level 10 missions.Basically, each "item" on your characters is 3-6 cards added to a "deck" from which you can potentially draw for your hand each turn, and these items are generated much like loot drops in an action RPG. Some items will provide a good mix of AOE cards, some items will provide direct damage, most items will be an unholy and utterly useless mishmash  with junk cards that you won't want in any situation and one card that you really want but probably will never draw because it comes buffered with garbage.Around level 10 you start getting encounters that you absolutely have to base your party gear (deck) around, and loot is pretty sparse. I liked the game enough to pay for a starter back wich gave me extra loot drop for most of my playtime, and am currently stuck in a quest that requires crowd control but I still never managed to find any good crowd control items (no up to level fire staves or axe based multi target attacks,) the few items I have will have 2 of the attack I want and 4 junk cards that I'll be more likely to draw.Despite that, the cash shop isn't strictly predatory, between level requirements on items and the fact that said items are fairly cheap to buy (it's just extremely hard to find something you want at the merchants,) but there will be wasted days where you'll grind lower level dungeons until merchant inventory resets, and there will be be a wall where each new mission takes 2-3 days of grinding before you beat it.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
												Card Hunter is a fun game and will give you a good 2-4 weeks of game play for no pay, unless you binge it--then you won't get as much out of it. Meh, your mileage may vary. I plateaued after a week, so take that for what it's worth. What's it like? Well, for an old guy like me, it's a pleasant bit of nostalgia. For younger players, it's a throwback to the old D&D tabletop games of well, my childhood--late 70's - early 80's, though a lot of the genre trappings of late 80's - late 90's are present. Let me tone it down a bit and explain.You get three generic characters with basic item slots. Pick an elf, dwarf, or human for each, and pick a warrior, mage, cleric for each. Each item slot grants access to certain cards you will play in battle. Adventuring leads to better gear which grants better powers. There is a rough storyline in the "real" world of the game where you are reading the things that others say to you.. a game master, his brother, the cute girl, etc. Nothing heavy or great. Some funny stuff, but very light. You can alternatively play multiplayer for quicker loot and gear. I waited until I finished the main campaign to engage in multiplayer, but you don't have to. I forget, however, how soon you can start, and the nice part is that the game lets you know.Each adventure has a little backstory you can read, as well as a little backstory in "real" life you can read as well. You move game pieces around a battle mat, taking turns with the computer. It's all pretty self-explanatory unless you're completely new to this sort of thing. The game holds your hand just long enough to get you up to speed, so don't worry if you are new. It's worth a try if you think you might like to experience a taste of tabletop roleplaying, without so much roleplaying--actually none. It's all hack and slash. Not complaining, just saying.Most of the campaign adventures were way too easy, but still fun for the most part. Later level adventures get significantly more difficult and sometimes require strategy as well as luck of the draw to win, depending on your gear and choices. The last few tended to be annoyingly difficult, but I can overlook that. I actually was more disappointed that the campaign stopped when it did. I wanted more solo play. You may feel differently. I get the feeling that the last few quests were uncharacteristically hard because someone felt it necessary to downplay the fact that there is no more free content afterward. Could be wrong, but I doubt it.The game gives you gold for completing quests and selling treasure rewards. Gear can't be sold until you make a few levels to decrease the chances you'll sell something you later wish you had kept. The game also gives you some pizza, which is the game currency that you will have to pay real cash to get once the freebies run out. They want you to spend it a certain way, which I think is a complete waste. Just my opinion. Here's a pro tip for you: If you can manage to play a LOT for a week, spend your pizza to get a one week membership. That way you'll get to keep the best treasures you earn rather than just gazing at them before moving on to the next battle. Because that's how it works, you open a chest and items appear. One item appears in a special box that you can only open if you are a paid member. Usually that item is a really good one. Not always, but early on it is. And don't laugh, some of those low level rares, epics, and legendaries are worth holding onto for later. Trust me.Now, about multiplayer. I find this aspect of the game more fun than playing chess with human beings. Some of the players are very good. Some are very arrogant and irritating. It's a mixed bag, but no better or worse than any other online community. Actually, it IS better than some communities. Here's another pro tip for you--for every game you ever play: Stay out of the online chat. The game developers have some strange ideas about who can play and who should be banned. Their game, their rules. I get it. Just not what I would do. I have kids who'd like to play the solo campaign, but nobody under the age of 13 is allowed to play. In a lot of ways that can be good, but if a good kid wants to play the solo adventures, I'm not sure why that's a problem. Remember when I mentioned my childhood- late 70's to early 80's? I was between the ages of 8 and 13 at that time. Just saying. Keeping the next generation of gamers away from your game isn't the smartest or most community-minded move, but rather a way of keeping old farts like me happy and spending money. But I digress. Anyway, there's also co-op, but I haven't played it, so I'm not going to comment on it. I will say, as for the pay aspect, in multiplayer, you can pretty much tell who's either spending most of their life in the game or spending cash to make it look as if they are.Anyway, if you think you'd like an interesting card game that uses tabletop pieces and strategy against human opponents that is easy to get into, you could do a lot worse. My biggest beef, however, is the way you kind of get forced into multiplayer after you finish the main quest, because, really, that's about all there is to do unless you pay to unlock extra adventures in the caimpaign map. Those may or may not be worth the dough. My guess is they are worth it if you like this game because, with the exceptions I noted above, the free content seems pretty much consistent overall. I enjoyed the game, but I didn't like it enough to spend the cash. It's worth trying.

They deserve it.Free to play, all classes, items and gameplay modes (singleplayer and multiplayer) are free.Pizza (cash) buys cosmetic items (character tokens), increases the speed of progress (extra loot per victory) and unlocks additional scenarios (so more loot/xp/fun per day). 												This game is a whole heck of a lot of fun.  It would be infinitely more fun if it didn't have all the things that try and make you pay for features.  Get rid of all the pizza that cost real money and all the things like that and this game would be a shoe in for number one for a long time.  There is no pay wall.  You can play the game without paying money but you miss out on a lot of little things that would make the game more fun.  Sure you could pay but it is not a one time financial commitment to unlock the game, it is a subscription based commitment.  So really you never really own the whole game.

Posted: July 2, 2016
												This is easily one of my favorite free to play games. The play system is a fun and unique blend of board game and card game and the storyline (I use the term lightly) is nerdily fun. I'm pretty sure anyone who has ever played real life D&D has had a "Melvin" in their group, and this game nailed it. Anyway the campaign is pretty extensive and is seeing new content fairly regularly and the multiplayer is fun with a friendly and helpful community. I can't recomend highly enough. So don't waste any more time, and begin the quest for more loot.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
												The game has promise, but it really feels like a D&D session run by an amaturish DM such as the one the game depicts. There are three classes (fighter, mage, cleric) and three races (human, elf, dwarf), each with a handful of mechanics you can build to focus on. But the encounters in the game increasing feel like, "there's one mechanic I want you to use this time, and by God if you don't abuse it, I will slaughter you." If you try to buck the system and play your own style, well...After the umpteenth time of watching the enemy roll four sixes in a row, and then watching my team fail to roll more than a two five times in a row ... you get the feeling that the RNG elements in this game are worse than stuff like Xcom or Fire Emblem. Then it takes four clicks to get back into the fight after getting the shaft from the random number god. It takes even more to bail out on an adventure sequence in progress. (You have to forfeit up to three times in a row to exhaust your continues). An example of bad RNG and balancing: Monsters almost always come in groups. This means they get to share a hand. That means any monster in the group can use all the attacks. But wait! It gets worse: every creature in the group gets to use all of the block and armor cards. Over and over again if they are keep cards. And you can stack armor cards. As deep as you want. (Think wyverns with a 3+ to ignore 4 damage and immunity to electricity, three cards deep. That's only a 3.5% chance of getting through!!!) Add that to the fact that monsters have what seems to be a dozen card deck (as opposed to the ~30-40 card deck players have), they always seem to draw what they need. I'm pretty sure the computer cheats to make unrevealed cards in the computers hand exactly what they need if the computer is losing. And you're guaranteed to draw at least one move card, but not attack/heal/magic for your three classes, so you frequently find yourself inundated with move cards. This gets frustrating as you only have 2 retries on a level before having to pay in-game currency so you can't save scum your way through this.It's also disappointing that there isn't some pay this much and remove all F2P elements from the game option. You can buy stuff, but there's no one way to get everything and the timers on the shops and levels remain regardless. The fact that your card club or whatever runs out on real time days and you rebuy it with pizza (ie, real money) is quite insidious. It's actually a subscription. I at least enjoyed the classic D&D aesthetic.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
												This could have been a good game.  I wanted to like it.  It has a sense of humor about old style RPGs, y'know.  Pencil & paper ones.But I can't like it.  The game play, while simple, is too frustrating.  In pretty much every single player scenario, luck rules the day.  You can design your gear as best you can, but drawing cards is random, and you can't save many from round to round.  Use em or lose em, regardless of any sense it makes to do.  Interestingly, while you get random draws, the AI seems to have a lot of very small numbers of options, so it -always- has exactly what it needs to kill you.Every time.So scenarios that claim they are for level 10 parties actually means you should be at least level 16 to have a chance of winning without trying it three dozen times, and it only lets you replay a certain number of times a day.  Then there's that pesky luck based award system that sometimes means you need to be even stronger than that.PvP is completely broken, with pay2win players dominating everything.  Even if you chance upon a less broken player in the completely random matching system, if you weren't lucky enough to have found decent equipment in the solo play, you are again screwed.  And when I say completely random, I mean it.  Your arena ranking number means absolutely nothing to the game and it will happily put you up against players who are far superior to your meager crap cards repeatedly.Good concept, good writing, wish I could see the rest of the story line, but I hate the game play too much to keep it installed on my computer.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												Card Hunter started out as a browser game and got me hooked before it's release on Steam.  It is a fusion of D&D and deckbuilding.  Every piece of loot you collect adds specific cards to each of your party members' decks.  You draw cards each turn and try to make the most out of your spells, melee attacks, heals, and movements.  Dice rolls are made with many of the blocking cards so there is an element of chance.  Other than that, the rest of battle is affected by how you build your decks.  This game is free so it's definately worth a try.  You can pay actual money to gain access to more loot, campaigns, and cosmetics.  If you like turn-based combat and/or deckbuilding, you'll love Card Hunter.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												I've played this for two years already via Blu Manchu's site. This is the only multiplayer game to date I've ever sank money into, mainly because I want to reward the devs for their hard work maintaining such a good game. But it's definitely not pay-to-win; I played free for six months before I decided to invest. The mechanics are simple, yet very deep in multiplayer, and there are multiple play styles and ways to win. There's a great community and the devs are friendly and approachable, and incorporate user feedback/content into the game. Get into it, it's great.

												Yes I know, I've only very briefly played this game but hear me out. For starters there's nothing inherently wrong with this game at first glance, it looks nice, plays well, decent gameplay, leveling system etc etc, I was all set to love this game appart from one massive game breaking (in my case) oversight, no resolution options ingame or pre-load, this lead to everything being "slightly to the right" of where my cursor actually was and by slightly I mean a good centimetre or two and yeah I could of grinned and bared it but frankly it ruined the game for me then and there, I slugged through the first level, tried to sort the resolution issue and then came here to write this review. Resolution support should be a standard in games these days, for that reason alone this isn't getting recommended but for a free game it's pretty good, pick it up if your monitor can support it.

												To say this is a free game Card Hunter  is oozing with content. If you have a couple of friends who you know will enjoy playing a D&D esque game then you should download it instantly as you will have hours of fun and entertainment. If you couldnt tell i highly recommend this game and believe that it is worth your time.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												I have been playing this game now for almost 2 years.  It's a great mix of turn based tactical game and collectable card game.  It is a F2P title but the developers are very good at developing a model that avoids the pay-to-win syndrome.  You can spent money to get random loots faster, buy certain premium quest modules, and cosmetic figure outfits.From my prospective, one of the best part about this game is the fact that each game could be done in 10-20 minutes or less and there's no problem with taking a break.  So it's a really good game for people who are busy and can't spent more than 30 - 40 minutes at a time.All in all, this game has kept me entertained for a long time now, and I look forward to additional contents from the developer to keep this game growing.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 24, 2016
												 Very fun aspects of the game. However there are two major issues that really limit it. First off the leveling system they have in place doesn't let you replay any previous dungeons if they are a couple levels below you. If you try your level will be drastically reduced, you won't get any experience whatsoever, and because of your artificially reduced level you will also now be too low level to use your own gear! So apparently you are expected to constantly lug around tons of worthless low level gear for your party just in case you want to play any scenario deemed below you (which is generally like 90 percent of them) and you will also get nothing whatsoever out of it. FUN! Second it's very micro transaction heavy. There are a very large number of skins, and now scenarios (including the new Penny Arcade ones) that you simply CANNOT play unless you pay. This is not an issue of paying to advance more quickly, this is literally walling off part of the game forever unless you pay up. I'd much rather just pay once for a full priced game than this nickel and dime b.s. Avoid until/if they ever figure out a better pay structure

content:
Posted: March 20, 2016
												There are plenty of reasons to play this game, but I cannot recommend it due to the game itself.It's easy to end up with no way to move out of an enemy that is stacked full of attacks that will kill you, but because you don't have any movement cards you're screwed.Due to this it's almost definitly a good thing to play as Elves because of their long movement range, but I do have a feeling that the game encourages you to play different races with different abilities.Due to the games cards it's very random if you succeed or fail a hard level, sometimes you can get wiped one play and utterly massacre the next due to RNG, so if you like that, Great! If you hate it? Well we will probably agree, it's not a fun game because of it.Then there is the proof of "Free to pay" game it is where it offers you special games and extra loot if you pay for a premium currency, however it's based in IRL time and it doesn't matter if you sunk 500 dollars on it earlier, if you just ran out you will be left without anything in the future. Unless you pay more.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												This game is so much fun. It's a board game that uses card game mechanics for combat, the cards in your deck are set by the equipment your characters have. The combat is in small 5 to 10 (usually) minute chunks so you can invest as much or as little time per session as you want. It's also an homage to old school D&D, with many of the chapters fashioned after classic modules. It is free with a P2P element, but (at least initially) it isn't as in your face as a lot of games are. Some people won't like paying the approximately $10-$12 to unlock content (a special dungeons pack and 2 expansions as of this writing each cost around that price) but it seems like there is enough content even without that. Did I mention there is PvP and multiplayer co-op? If you like strategy board games, card games, or old school D&D, you will love this game. Highest recommendation.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
												This is one of the few games that brings solid DnD card gameplay with fantastic visuals and sound! I must say that I did not even know this game existed last week and stumbled across it randomly... saw that it was free to play so I was worried at first and decided to download it. After installing it and playing through to my Keep I was in awe, finally a small gem of a game in this age of uncompleted post-beta games and never completed pre-release games. Card Hunter is a very addictive and fun ride I must say! After the first hour I went and bought myself the Basic Bundle, which was 20 bucks (or 26 in canadian sigh) and about two hours later I bought the first expansion. If you enjoy turn based DnD style games then this one you simply can't pass up, considering it is free!I would have to say the only downside for me is when buying the bundles as it's price (American but no warning) and the way I have to use my Steam Wallet through the game menu to purchase it was the only frustrating part of it. Overall this game I would give a solid 8/10 as there is so much to do and even more I have not seen! Cheers!

content:
Posted: August 19, 2015
												Well, this game is a bit of fun, but falls short of its potential.First, the nerdy GM should say everything that he's saying in written form instead of just instant comments.Second, there should be choices between encounters that would affect the battle in question (allies, dependants, wounded monsters or heroes, (de)buffed heroes or monsters, etc.) according to the choices made. Otherwise why call this a role-playing game since there is no roleplaying? Gaining levels is not a roleplaying game that's a level-up game.Third, combat is simple, somewhat fun and does not take forever to go through one fight. I don't like the card system for armour, it's dumb, you are either wearing your armour or not, it should not depend on your cards, it's silly. Skills on the other hand should, even though I find that silly too but it's a card game. Permanent items like armour and shields should always be in effect and not count as a card. There are some challenging fights out there too.Fourth, microtransactions, yay! I'd rather buy the game that being faced with begging Devs, because that's how I see game devs that puts micro trans in their game, beggars. You can go far in the game without using any mt.Fifth, having an adventure where you explore an area would be great. It wouldn't be just hack'n'slash turn-based.I recommend barely this game, I think the dev / pub should sell this game and remove all micro trans from it. The mts are really not worth any real money. I won't waste money to make one, and only one of my character look different. Why the hell would I want to pay for that?If you don't like micro-transactions, stay away from this game. But since it's free for a good way, try it out if you like Hack'n'slash tactical games.

number of helpful: 19 of 41 people (46%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
												I played this game a lot for a couple weeks when it originally released as a browser game. Its a good concept for a TBSRPG that is sadly marred by some bad browser game interfaces and worst of all, horrendously predatory cash shop practices. DL'd the steam version hoping they were satisfied with what they've inevitably milked out of saps with a longing in their heart for the ol' tabletop. Evidently they are not. If you want to enjoy even the single player element completely it'll run you 30ish bucks for the 2 "expansions" plus an additional SUBSCRIPTION fee (lol). Even purchasing the 20 dollar (ON SALE!!) premium "basic edition" pack only gets you one month of their, frankly revolting, subscription based grind aid. Needless to say the multiplayer element is essentially pointless in any numbers game with a cash shop, so there's that as well.Ultimately, the gameplay is pretty solid. I would definitely recommend giving the single player a whirl for a bit if you feel interested. Just do not spend a single red cent on anything in the game if you have any respect for yourself or video games in general. It is truly a shame they didn't just release this game on a buy to play basis for steam, or at least let you permanently upgrade to a "bought edition" instead of keeping the micro-trans, and the ludicrous subscription-to-a-browser-game concept, firmly in place.

number of helpful: 13 of 29 people (45%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
												There's really three aspects to this game - campaign, special campaign levels, and multiplayer.Campaign is entertaining for a few hours, before it becomes obvious how it's the same over and over. Then it's and endlessly repetitive grind. Also somewhat too easy on every level. Special campaign levels (Mauve Manticore) really goes the opposite way as the mother of all RNGs. You are forced into 30-50+ retries just because it was literally impossible with the cards you were given. Like you have 4 turns to kill an enemy and you are given no weapon cards, just block and move. As the special campaign levels are visible on the campaign map like every other level, I really want to complete them - but it's seriously idiotic how they are 98% RNG-dependent. Buying all the DLC is $45. Multiplayer I haven't tried.

number of helpful: 6 of 15 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 21, 2015
												I started off liking this game, but as a fan of strategy games over time increasingly I found less to like about playing it. As you advance the game pits you against increasingly stacked odds. The problem is your cards are all drawn random, so if you do not get just the right draw combination on many maps there is no recovery and you have to start over. Not that random cards are totally bad, it is just that your opponent does not seem to follow the same rule. Your cards are random but the computer seems to have attack cards, move cards and defense every turn. Random cards for the PC would have balanced play but it does not appear to be designed that way.Some may like this style but to me anyway this totally negates strategy in the game, it comes down to random card draws and luck. If you find frustration and yelling at the computer when you need an attack card and get all move cards, die and have to start over, this is the game for you. Me personally it is being uninstalled. Nice idea to mirror an old table top game, but poor implementation.

Posted: October 29, 2015
												game is good for a few minutes, until you realize that it is just a money grab. as you progress LITERALY half of the levels are unplayable (locked) unless you pay REAL money to unlock them. the few levels that are unlocked get brutal so that they force u to play levels that you have already beaten OVER AND OVER AND OVER AND OVER until you hopefully FINALLY get a level and can try to beat the game breaking levels pit you against enemies that can hit you from clear accross the map, and kill you before you can even make it near them. on top of that, the entire looting system is a grab at your money.. as they show you the loot that you COULD have on a pillow.. then, when u pay the money for a 7 day loot expansion or whatever, the quality of the loot goes down, in an attempt to get you to pay even more money for further rewards. i am so tired of people taking a half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ decent idea.. then just ruining it with greed and lies. this game is in no way FREE TO PLAY. if anything, this game is 'free to attempt to play.' meaning that the game will force you into monotany if you dont give it cash. if you dont pay cash the level curves will force you to spend DAYS literally DAYS playing the same lower levels for SEVERELY reduced rewards. i have lost all faith in steam at this point.. every other game on steam is a pay to win game anymore.. riddled with bugs, released way before its finished, and constantly pushing for you to spend real money in game... it doesnt make any sense.. how has gaming become this? i used to be proud to be a nerd, and proud to be a gamer.. playing real games, like Azure Dreams, Final Fantasy Tactic, Star Ocean, etc.. now it is a sickening grab for cash, a disgusting expoitation of our love for gaming.. this isnt even a game, like most steam games, it appears to be a game, however, it is really just a machine that is designed to lure you in with lies, gain your interest, then exploit you for money if you want to experience the game properly.. im sickened.. truly sickened by this game.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2016
												As a fun game to kill time, i can't recommend it, because it's Luck: The Game.Your cards are drawn randomly, so you can get, for example only moving cards when you need to kill last enemy, or only attack cards when you are far away from any enemy. And since you need to discard all but two cards in hand, at the end of the round, you can't do any elaborate tactics, if you lack the walking/attacking card.Also some (i mean most) cards have random chance to activate, eg: roll +4 to block attack; for some reason enemies can roll 6 all the time, which means your attack does nothing, while your block/parry get 1-2, means enemies get all the damage on you.

content:
Posted: April 27, 2016
												Pay to winThe campaign is fun to play through the first time. The multiplayer is not fun. The futuristic direction made previous cards useless. The RWG on loot and during play gets old. The random generation generally doesn't give you enough rare cards in relation to how many times you have to win against players who simply bought their decks. There is rampant cheating and people taking advantage of leaderboard mechanics. Cheaters can see your cards and magically have a counter. People take advantage of the leaderboards by intentionally trashing their own rank in order to get "consecutive wins". The mechanics of how cards work is also confusing. Combinations are difficult to create unless you spend the time to understand the mechanics of a card rather than what it actually says.It was fun for a while but, it's not sustainable gameplay.

number of helpful: 7 of 18 people (39%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
												Solid game that is, in my opinion, hurt by a reliance on luck.I may come back and do an expanded review later, but for now I'll keep this short. The game on its face is fun, but the combat relies HEAVILY on random dice rolls. A string of bad rolls WILL mean that you fail a mission, no matter how skilled you are or how well you've built your characters. Add to that the enemies seeming to get very powerful cards just a little ways into the game (rank 7 missions, and even earlier) and it can get immensely frustrating incredibly quickly. It may be that enemies have smaller decks than the player characters do, which means key cards (armor, powerful attacks, etc) come up more than they do for the player, or it may just be my poor luck, but at the end of the day, when no amount of strategy can win in the face of a string of bad luck, I can't recommend this game. In my opinion, a certain degree of luck in games is fine, but when the ability to even make an attack comes down to luck of the draw, I think that hurts the game. It's not a bad game by any means when the other components are taken into consideration (art is good, the tone of the game is humorous, and the mechanics for character progression and deck building are fun) but it is very frustrating when battles are won or lost based almost purely on RNGs.

number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2015
												TL;DR I would not recommend CardHunter. The game mechanics are interesting and fun but it is pay-to-not having to grind and you are playing an RPG without story or immersion or atmosphere.It is such a shame that a really great idea for mechanics is wasted because of greediness (asking money for content and loot) and laziness (no story, animations, atmosphere).PROs:- Game mechanics are unique and interesting. It is basically a puzzle game (which gear to equip for which battle) meet tactical combat a la XCOM.- The whole "meta" aspect - you play someone who is playing a game - is funny (for about 15 minutes).CONs:- The devs ask you every 5 seconds for real money. Big portions of the game are only available when paying for it. Image that in The Witcher you are being asked to pay 4 Euros to enter this dungeoun. The game really is all about loot (cards). Every single action a character can perform - even to walk - comes from cards which come from equipment. Loot is everything, levels are nothing. Now, you can grind your way to victory over countless hours or simply pay cash to get loot. At the same time, the  price per month is about the same as for a triple A MMORPG, WTH?- Multiplayer is very asymmetrical, players do not get even chances because single player loot is used.

												The game is fun up until about level 5 level 6ish where you can't play any further due to lack of proper cards and gear. This is where the 'f2p' ends and you have to start fishing out real money to buy 'pizza' to buy gear or subscribe so you get the bonus gear in dungeons which is even MORE money. OR you can go back and grind a few dungeons, BUT this requires anything that you used a power core on to be removed because you no longer have that. So you lose equipment in order to redo earlier dungeons which makes them pretty much as difficult as they were the first time around FOR LESS EXP AND GEAR than the first time you ran it. So it is all pointless if you don't plan on spending money. On top of the fact that you can't really redo a dungeon unless you wait a day for it to cooldown in order to get as much as you can out of it. Its a good timekiller for about 30 minutes and then it requires cash. Would not play again, deleting it from my steam.
