Posted: August 25, 2015
												4/5 ****  Thumbs up and thanks to Pyrosaur for the recommendation.  This amusingly fun-filled game harkons back to the old table top pencil and paper Dungeons and Dragons system of the 1970's.  There's even a running gag between the host and his older brother.  Others have fairly observed Card Hunter to be a combination of D&D and Magic (cards).   I suppose you could spend as much time as you like on deck tuning, but unlike Magic, Card Hunter doesn't require that to be competitive or enjoyable.  This system connects assets, like a weapon, armor, etc., to a subsetn (3 - 8 ish) of cards that become available in the respective characters deck.  During play you draw and play certain cards.  Random events are resolved based on the cards, many have a d6 check built in.  For example, an armor card may give 2 protection if you roll 4 or more.  Unlike Magic, there aren't suits or colors to worry over.  Card selection is relatively simple and as a player you are free to escape your mind and enjoy.  I recommend you do so!

Posted: August 13, 2015
												I will just make a brief review here.Card Hunter is like a board game, but not your ordinary board game. It's quite simple and casual but still 'deep' enough for people who are not really into casual stuff. The things I like from this game are:1. It has a unique system that a character's deck is built from whatever equipments the character has. 2. RPG element, characters can be levelled up. 3. All characters are free to recruit from the first level. If you feel that you have picked a character that does not fit your style of play, just go recruit another one.4. You can name your character5. You can play alone or together with your friends, no problem.6. The artwork is good, I like it7. It's FREE!! Why are you hesitating??Other things (not bad, not good, but maybe you might want to know):1. Costume/cosmetic is only represented by the character token. Real money is needed for these character tokens, they are not cheap but not really important either. 2. Everytime you cleared a battle in campaign mode, you will get loots. There will be an extra loot on each post-battle screen, you could only get that random extra loot if you're some kind of a premium member (this involves real money). The extra random items are not always good.3. There are also some storylines/campaigns which need your money to be able to be unlocked.4. Is this P2W? So far I can't give you that answer yet because I only play on the co-op mode :PI rarely engage in the PVP mode but so far the single and co-op mode has been fun for me.

This game is exactly what I didn't know I had been looking for.The game perfectly and seamlessly blends the tabletop feeling of dungeons and dragons, with the amazing combat system this game has created. Posted: July 31, 2015
												As a person who has put a fair amount of time into the game I have to say that this game was something I really wanted to like. It had many components that you would think would fit perfectly well, but the main problem with this game is: The game has this repetitive grind to it because it makes you fight the RNG (random number generater),especially near the end of the campaign. The missions/modules/enemies always seem to have a major advantage. Never have I seen an enemy without at least one attack nomatter what when they draw while more than likely I seem to go for rounds without getting anything but move cards. Enemies sometimes come in hordes which seem not bad since most hordes just share form a single deck but the problem start to arise when you notice that while you take a whole turn to move one character, for the enemy actually takes one turn to move everyone.Theres also the fact that the enimes have better cards than you most of the time which don't make much sense for the levels sice you can only come in within certain levels and if your overlevelled then you have to lose some cards and power tokens to make it "fair"The game rolls seems rigged. I can't tell how many times that this game gave me a hand that could comlete annilate a foe but for some reason ALL its defence cards block everything, even when my cards have stuff like "hard to block" or they have "bad luck"(it essentially makes it s the dice roll goes down by 1), it gets so lucky and procs each and every block card.I mean theres one level in particular which is called "Return to the Astral Shrine" which essentially is impossible for me because even with armour destoying cards, bad luck and any other cards that make enemies lose cards, the enemies in that room just make it impossible because thay always have a card that blocks 5 damage, they only need to roll a 4 ad it doesn't matter whether is works or not they keep that card. But the problem with that is that they seem to always have one of those cards in there hand no matter how many times you destroy it! I mean I once save two cards that did 14 damage each so I unleashed it on one foe and it happend to have two armour cards which successfully rolled a +4 for both of the attacks I did, which lead to my attack that had the chance to do 28 damage to do a total of 8.Overall, I think that this game has it's charm but the fact that even though it's free to play, it feels like it tries to rig the game and force you to buy so that you can actually progress.

Posted: July 31, 2015
												Overall I love Card Hunter. They were able to successfully blend my favorite aspects of gaming into one epic package. Between the campaign mode and multiplayer, I could easily see myself logging hundreds of hours into this game if I had the free time to do so. The only reason I can’t give this a solid 5/5 is due to the micro-transactions along with the expansions and club membership. They are just being a little too greedy when it comes to sucking money out of the pockets of fellow gamers, and games like these are hard for me to recommend on a moral level. If someone who respects my opinions got hooked onto this game and ends up spending thousands of dollars due to micro-transactions, I couldn’t help but feel slightly responsible. If you are not someone that is easily suckered into this business scheme, then I highly recommend this game. You can enjoy Card Hunter without ever spending a dime, or at least never buying any Pizza. If you are someone that can’t help but spend money in a game in order to gain the upper hand or speed up the grinding process, I urge to you to stay away from this game, and any others that condone this set-up.Check out my full review on our site, and feel free to let me know what you thought of my opinions!  http://www.steamfirst.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=10267&action=edit

Posted: August 19, 2015
												This game gives me a Card-on

Posted: August 19, 2015
												Don't get me wrong it's a nice concept, a simplified version of DnD without the hastle of trying to learn how to build characters through an ocean of content. But the way it is now some things need to change. Most situations feel like they need to be handled by more then 3 team members and the game overwhelms you in later missions with large amounts of NPCs that are both small damage and large damage leaning more in the favor of large damage enemies. Usually ending with you trying to prioritize the high damage enemies but taking too much damage or losses to consider the exchanges worth while.Pros:Simple:Easy to learn, your abilities are based on the equipment you have, enemies aren't overcomplicated time bombs you don't want to go near, races are genericly balanced, and classes have designated equips.Great Fun with Friends:Co-op with friends is a blast, makes everything twice as fun.Comedic Writing:The game can be funny at times making it feel more worthwile to play through the campaignEquiment:Easy to understand, a little hard to obtain without grinding lower level missions, and equipment is balanced with major and minor power tokens so you aren't a complete god against the AI.Easy to Change:You don't have to stick to one party, you can buy new party members for a low cost of ingame currency and interchange party members at any time to fit your play style.Cons:Classes aren't what they seem to be:The classes can be built one of two ways, either all aggression or complete support roles. There are no effective in betweens because you're either losing out on damage or don't help the other members in your team.Wizards aren't at all DPS, most spells at a wizard's disposal are weak or are easily snuffed out by enemy armors/blocks. Also most beginning damage spells are close range that deal no damage, meaning you have to sit in damage range just to do damage and this follows you well into mid game depending on your load out. The wizards that can control spells that manipulate the battlefield have no damage what so ever. Priests are squishy supports that can't stay in combat very long for the same reason, they do almost no damage. With the all aggression priests they have almost no support and once again can't stay in combat because they can't take a hit.Warriors are either high damage DPS with no range or medium DPS with range. Warriors aren't tanks either considering most NPCs will just chip off 50% or more of your member's HP without even trying. Warriors either move into range and then have the target immediatly move out of range afterwards or do little to no damage with longer range attacks.Equipment:It will screw you again and again, most equipment is either okay but nothing substantial. Anything that's good either has terrible draw backs from using them or require so many power tokens you can't use anything else that's good until you're high level. Your equipment is determind by RNG so you might just get a bunch of stuff for warriors or priests, but get nothing for your mage. Essentially making that unit completly worthless unless you do a grindfest or buy new overpriced equipment. Main issues with equipment is you're forced to use low level equipment even though your other gear is leagues ahead of it and it's mainly useless in your missions. There isn't any scaling in gear level, you have your low level gear that doesn't require power tokens, mid range gear that requires minor power tokens, and high grade gear that requires either major power tokens or both major and minor power tokens. At max level team members, you only get 4 major power tokens and 4 minor tower tokens. Which you have to try and prioritize certain equipment slots over others, making you weak extremely weak in one department and strong in another. The Warrior class has 9 equipment slots, Mage 10 slots, and Priests with 10 slots. With most late game gear using 2 major power tokens you're already missing half your stock for only one equipment item. So now you're stuck trying to build for pure DPS or pure support for certain classes. There is no effective inbetween for both offensive and defensive builds, they both work against each other and flood your hand with either or, not a mixture of both.Gold/Shop:Making gold is stupidly hard uphill battle of RNG and selling extra equipment for almost nothing to buy new equipment. To be actually able to sell back items you don't use you need to get a renown of 7, probably about 8 or so campaign missions. Their main reason in doing this is to have players build a good amount of equipment before going and blindly selling off equipment they aren't using. Main issue with this is once you get to sell items they aren't worth much of anything unless it's rare or legendary equipment which still sells for a crappy amount of gold. Common equipment is usually worth around one to two gold, where rare and legendary sell for around 50 to 100 gold. Selling one legendary piece of equipment gets you enough gold to buy one mediocre item from the shop. Your main way of making gold is selling common extras of equipment and cheap treasure with your occasional semi-precious treasure.NPCs and RNG are jerks:NPCs won't move unless you do most of time making it hard to determine how to plan for a situation, most times the NPCs seem to be well aware of what you possess in your hand. NPCs seem to just get cards that undermine everything you try to do. They either have so much armor and block you can't do anything or their rolls against you and for themselves feel rigged in their favor most of the time. Most of their saving rolls are 4+ and they seem to get the rolls they need flawlessly at most points in time. My armors and blocks have a saving roll of 2 or better and I still end up failing them 90% of the time.Races:The different races don't work well together at all. Dwarves are all tank but no movement which makes them pair terribly with humans and elves because they just leave them behind in the dust. If you're going to play with a dwarf you might as well make the rest of your party dwarves and play defensivly. The only good time to have one dwarf is as a mage because they don't have to be front line. Humans are a balance of both health and movement making them your go tos for optional play styles and are able to switch between aggressive and passive play styles. Elves are all mobility with no health making them get in and out characters or complete avoidance characters. You're not staying in combat with elves, you're either dashing in to do a little damage then dashing out or attacking from afar. Elves don't pair well with other races because they just leave the other races behind and end up over extending themselves.Little to no hand manipulation:There are barely any card draws and some of them punish you for trying to get new cards that are better for the situation. There is little to no enemy hand manipulation unless you can specificly build for it and land the ability through the NPC's/Player's saving roles. So far the only enemy hand manipulation cards I have seen remove their oldest block or all of them or remove armor cards. Enemy NPC's will most likely do this to themselves before you even know what to use to manipulate their hand.My current stand point with this game is neutral, I love the concept but hate the way the game is going at the moment. I'm left here to hope they change some of these glaring issues before I loose all interest for a game that punishes players for trying to build for multiple utilities. If you want to play it for fun's sake with friends you'll probably enjoy this game for a few sessions. But if you want to seriously play all the way to the end power to you, because this game is brutal with it's RNG and rolls for saves. To be able to continue to play for me there needs to be a serious rebalance with how classes work, how card draw works, and how the rolls/RNG work.

Posted: September 5, 2015
												An amazing little turn-based tactical strategy game with an old school fantasy RPG flavor.  Position your adventurers on a grid map and do battle with monsters using the spells and fighting techniques represented by cards that your adventurers get from the equipment you choose to equip them with.  It has a decent competative MOBA multiplayer as well as a 2-3 player co-op campaign.  The purple prose of the modules provokes just the right amount of nostalgia to invoke OG Dungeons and Dragons.  The competative balance ebbs and flows with each expansion, but is generally pretty good.  The difficulty of the singleplayer/coop campaign varies WILDLY depending on the specific scenerio, any handycaps you may choose to apply, and how you spec your toons.Expansions/DLC are fun and flavorful if somewhat short and occationally punishingly hard.Overall a very nicely designed TSG with a good deal of depth and a strong competitive following.  Can be a little hard even for a vetern of the genre in places, the campaign does get stale after a while, and it can be frustrating to grind for a single high level item among the multitude of random drops, but these complaints pale in comparison to the game's many charms.

Posted: September 8, 2015
												now it's not often i put money into a free game.  the only Free 2 Play game i've put any money at all into was Warframe and that's only because i didn't want to get rid of my stuff (collection nut here :P ) but Card Hunters is just so fricken great that i'd put money into it.  it mixes tabletop DND with a deck building game where your character's equipment decides what cards are in your deck, then when you've equipped your characters, it tosses you into battles where you're literally looking down at a board with your characters as little, old-fashioned, flat cardboard pieces on plastic stands.  it's so damn cool!  as a 90s kid i grew up playing board games with pieces like that so this is a total throwback, but at the same time it's fresh, new, and just so god damn cool!  there's nothing else to say.  out of 5 stars, this gets 1,000,000!  some may say this is a bit over the top, but i just love this game!  plain and simple!  just love it to little bitsies! *squee* and i'm done.

												I love turn-based strategy, and this is one of the best. The way that it blends tactical RPG with deck-building is inspired. Posted: September 16, 2015
												I have fully enjoyed my time playing this game thus far and, for a sound investment of $0, it's one of my cheaper experiences. The combat flows extraordinarily well and is pretty easy to understand.However, this game does come with some notable flaws: Card draw and deck size. There are a few cantrips scattered throughout what I've seen so far, some even going so far as to allow you to take another action after drawing the card. These lack of cantrips can seriously drag a game on or even completly screw an attempt over. You can continue to draw only movement cards, or armor cards, or block cards. This gets highly frustrating, especially when it happens two, three, or even four rounds in a row. Being able to opt into slimming your deck size down might help this a little bit. Perhaps this is handled later on down the line and I just haven't gotten to it.On the other hand, it does have some great mechanics. Your choice of cards (or, rather, items which have cards attached to them) plays out as a big "Risk vs. Reward" when comparing cards from a single tier. Do you want an armor that has three "Armor 1. Keep."s, or one that has one "Armor 1. Keep.", one "Armor 2. Roll 4+", and one "Armor 2. Keep. Roll 4+"? Further, the usage of monster groups that use a card pool is a very clever idea that I for one would never have considered; it helps to balance out combat between 3 player characters and many more enemies without bogging down combat by making groups move at once.Overall, it's an awesome game. Highly recommend it.

Posted: July 16, 2015
												When I had made it through my first hour of gameplay I quickly returned to the store page to write a short  review about how much better this game was than trying to play a boring old table top. But now after more than 12 hours sunk into card hunter I find it harder to recomend. The story is funny and the characters are cheesy enough to feel like real nerds. But after a while the game looses all sense of expansion. Or to put that another way: it runs out of fresh ideas very quickly. After you finish the first level you have literally done everything there is to do in this game. Kill everything on the table, play an attack card for 10 damage that looses 9 points of its power to the 4 armor cards that every enemy has. Thats it. By all means play this game. Its good for a few hours of fun for people like me who cant stand DND, but for gods sake dont go thinking this can ever compare to a serious table top campaign. I know people that have games that are over 2 years old and still going. So yeah. Good time killer, just dont expect to get too invested in it.

Posted: September 9, 2015
												I'm now over 100 hours into the game, and I'm still having a lot of fun.This game is incredibly well crafted and thoroughly enjoyable.  I love the pen-and-paper feel, the gaming jokes, and the aesthetics of the game. I find the mechanics to be well thought out and quite balanced so far.  Strategy is required both in character set-up and battlefield execution.   I have no complaints, other than I'd love for it to have a deeper role-playing element.  However, this never intended to be Baulder's Gate 2, so I can live with that.The tournaments add a lot of variety to a game that already has a lot of options.  Rather than forcing one type of gameplay on players, Blue Manchu has provided fixed deck tournaments, quick draw tournaments (where you select cards from various options), chess-like tournaments - really, it's all quite a lot of fun.Great job by the developers.  Don't ignore this game because it's freemium.  It's a lot of fun even from the start, and is incredibly easy to pick up.

												A lot of people here mentioned that the AI's deck is always stronger than yours. They have access to harder hitting attacks and stronger and more reliable blocks. And this is true.It's also part of the game to try and overcome it by switching out gear and trying new tactics. For a free to play game, this game has a lot of replayability. Try it out for size.

Posted: September 23, 2015
												Card Hunter is a fun little hybrid of turn based strategy and card game.  You pick a race which sets how fast you are and how many HP you have(Dwarves, Humans, and Elves with dwarves having the most health, elves the most speed, and humans being in the middle for both) and a class which'll be the source of most of the cards in your deck(warriors tend to have lots of close up damage and armor, wizards use lots of ranged attacks plus enemy crippling effects, clerics have healing and support cards plus pretty solid melee damage of their own although not as consistent as a warrior) and along with race define your HP(with warriors having the most HP, wizards the least, and clerics in the middle).  You'll have three characters in your party for most of the game. Your deck is decided by your equipment.  For example if you have a suit of armor you'll add three cards to your deck depending on what that armor gives you.  It might for example offer two cards that have a 50% chance of reducing damage by two and one card that will always reduce damage by two.  Generally speaking better gear requires you to use power orbs(which you get at certain levels, don't worry, they never go away.  If you equip gear that needs less orbs they go back to a general pool for you to access) or will have a negative card mixed in that harm you somehow.  Sometimes both.   Battles involve you drawing two cards a turn from a deck decided by what you have equipped as well as automatically drawing one free movement card based on your race(so three cards total per turn).  You always discard down to two cards at the end of each turn if you have more than two.  You use these cards to outmaneuver and outfit the various scenerios.  Most scenerios are pretty straightforward "Kill them before they kill you" setups although a fair number throw extra wrinkles into this mechanic.  Positioning matters(for example block cards....both yours and your opponents will not work against back attacks, also some attacks do more damage from behind or have extra effects).  All in all it's a fun game and it's also free.  There are extra levels that cost money to access but that's strictly optional.  I've gone through the core campaign and had quite a bit of fun with it.  Membership lets you win an extra award for each level you beat but once again, not necessary.  You don't get unique access to gear by having membership, it just increases your odds of getting something you want since you'll get one extra reward.   It's actually very easy to get stuff even without membership.One other thing to remember.  Deck building matters.  You will need to change your gear out on some levels to pass them.  One level might have enemies that love messing with terrain meaning you'll need gear to specifically to get around them while another might be loaded with fast long ranged enemies meaning more stuff that has ranged attacks or extra movement will matter.  If you find a level dominating you, look at your gear and what cards it has and figure out what will help with the level.  I've only foudn a few levels that really require this but they do exist.  Finally remember this is a strategy card game, not a RPG.  Don't go into it expecting much story.  It has a few amusing lines from the "characters" in it, but ultimately it's about building a solid deck and having a good strategy to handle each level.  Oh, and sometimes the randomness of cards will kill you through no fault of your own.  This is the exception rather than the rule but realize that it will happen occasionally like with any card game.  No matter how good your deck sometimes you'll just draw a dud hand for the situation in question.  Such is the way of random draws.

												now it's not often i put money into a free game.  the only Free 2 Play game i've put any money at all into was Warframe and that's only because i didn't want to get rid of my stuff (collection nut here :P ) but Card Hunters is just so fricken great that i'd put money into it.  it mixes tabletop DND with a deck building game where your character's equipment decides what cards are in your deck, then when you've equipped your characters, it tosses you into battles where you're literally looking down at a board with your characters as little, old-fashioned, flat cardboard pieces on plastic stands.  it's so damn cool!  as a 90s kid i grew up playing board games with pieces like that so this is a total throwback, but at the same time it's fresh, new, and just so god damn cool!  there's nothing else to say.  out of 5 stars, this gets 1,000,000!  some may say this is a bit over the top, but i just love this game!  plain and simple!  just love it to little bitsies! *squee* and i'm done.

Posted: September 10, 2015
												I'm a fan of deck-building games, but this isn't really recommendable.This is fun for the first 6-8 character levels.  There is a nice table-top RPG flavor with the nerdy Dungeon Master commenting on the little adventures.  It is a little taste of nostalgia for those who used to play D&D in the old days.I can't recommend this because outside of the nostalgia hit with light humor this isn't much game here.And while it was entertaining enough for a few hours of entertainment, if you do not have a perfect internet connection the game will drop you and force you to reconnect to the server.  Repeatedly.There is seriously no reason an extremely simple single-player campaign game like this needs to be connected to the server at all times.  It smacks of blizzard's implementation of the new Starcraft, except this game is free.It is hard to lose at lower levels, but as you get to around level 8 dungeons suddenly things get ridiculous.  A shark-bear ate my cleric in the first round with three bites, destroying her armor with the first bite.  A shark-bear is mildly humorous... but, meh.Then I went back to the board and my question asking, "Why is there a ridiculous constant internet connection requirement?" was removed from the board.I read the negative review stating that around level 10 you need to start buying the in-game pizza currency with real money to be competitive.Then I deleted Card Hunter from my game library.  It was kind of wacky and mildly fun for a bit, but that's it.

Posted: September 16, 2015
												I have fully enjoyed my time playing this game thus far and, for a sound investment of $0, it's one of my cheaper experiences. The combat flows extraordinarily well and is pretty easy to understand.However, this game does come with some notable flaws: Card draw and deck size. There are a few cantrips scattered throughout what I've seen so far, some even going so far as to allow you to take another action after drawing the card. These lack of cantrips can seriously drag a game on or even completly screw an attempt over. You can continue to draw only movement cards, or armor cards, or block cards. This gets highly frustrating, especially when it happens two, three, or even four rounds in a row. Being able to opt into slimming your deck size down might help this a little bit. Perhaps this is handled later on down the line and I just haven't gotten to it.On the other hand, it does have some great mechanics. Your choice of cards (or, rather, items which have cards attached to them) plays out as a big "Risk vs. Reward" when comparing cards from a single tier. Do you want an armor that has three "Armor 1. Keep."s, or one that has one "Armor 1. Keep.", one "Armor 2. Roll 4+", and one "Armor 2. Keep. Roll 4+"? Further, the usage of monster groups that use a card pool is a very clever idea that I for one would never have considered; it helps to balance out combat between 3 player characters and many more enemies without bogging down combat by making groups move at once.Overall, it's an awesome game. Highly recommend it.

Posted: October 23, 2015
												Strikes a surprisingly good balance of fun vs profit for a pay2win game.The single player campaign is well tuned and will leave you wanting more, which is where the independently purchasable modules come in. Since you're purchasing actual content, it doesn't leave you feeling sullied when you hand over the cash, even if the individual purchases ultimately add up to the cost of a AAA game.The power token system ensures that even very early game loot will have a place in your end-game party builds. Higher level gear requires more and more tokens, you'll never possess enough tokens that you can deck your character entirely in high level gear. It's a clever idea, and well implemented.I haven't touched the multiplayer, but this is where, I imagine, the pay2win issues are a little more at the forefront. There are no item rarity restrictions, and legenday / rare items are a very powerful and central part of many pvp builds.Protip: When starting out, you'll be given pizza to spend on costumes and chests. You don't have to do so. Spend that pizza on card hunter club membership instead, it will make playing the campaign much more enjoyable.

Posted: October 22, 2015
												Long before Card Hunter arrived on Steam, I was obsessed with it. It's a perfect combination of an old school dungeon-spelunking aesthetic and a newfanged deck-building card engine. You can have plenty of fun for free, and there's no need to spend any money unless you want to speed up your progression (useful but not necessary to complete the campaign) or unlock the expansion content. The developers are also very open to the community on social media, and I like to feel that I contributed in a small way by helping to get the original war monkeys nerfed!

Posted: December 5, 2015
												What a great and refresing take on free to play.  An elegent and fun mix of card game mechanics and table top gaming, with a great and almost nostalgic visual presentation.This Turn Based strategy is great for anyone who wants to play D&D and just can't find a group of their own.  The game itself is very approachable and forgiving to its player.  It delivers a lot of those generic scenarios, with some great and funny exposition from your Dungeon Masters during play.  Race, Class and gear dictate your abilities, which are sorted out into decks that the player draws from each round. Posted: July 18, 2015
												Wow, what a cool little game and it's great that it's free (with in game payments if you want to do that).This is a game all about quick tactical combats while your group of fantasy adventurers are out making their legend.  The game revolves around the CCG element where you use certain cards to do different powers.  The cards you have are dictated mainly by the gear you find and equip which you earn from doing questsYou can choose from three races (Human, Elf, Dwarf) and three classes (Warrior, Mage, Priest).  It doesn't sound like much considering that so many games have so many optionsYou can play solo, co op with friends or other randoms or even play ranked vs others you don't know. I honestly thought I'd just get this and go yeah it's free and kill a few hours with it, but I quickly became addicted.  It's fast, fun and I love the way combats flow.Give it a try.

Posted: July 18, 2015
												For those of us who were nerds and played the classic D&D, AD&D, and all the other iterations of this genre, there is so much that's familiar with it that brings back memories.  For those of us who were into Magic when it came out and are still involved w/ it or it's various forms, this game should be very comfortable w/ you too, since it is a card based combat system that is driven on the type of gear that you have.  This makes you want to collect everything since the mini-campaigns require you to customize your equipment loadout so that you have the cards to succeed in them. Lastly, for those of us who have played a bizillion  F2P games, this game should be one of your favs b/c of the minimal in your face, hard sale, micro transaction, premium status type models that you so commonly see. All in all, this game is a great combination of all three, that imo combines many of the great traits of the above mentioned game types w/o bogging you down.  It ties everything together w/ a lightly humourous, sarcastic campaign narration and a very engaging game play system that hooks you and threatens to destroy human relationships b/c you're hooked on trying to complete that next mini-campaign or do the next PvP or co-op. :p  The entire system is relatively simple to understand and is easy to get into quickly.  That is it's best and worst traits.  Limited with a 3 character party, with 3 playbable races, and 3 playable classes; there are calls about expanding party size, race and classes.  If this happens, like in any developing game that starts out great and fun, game play and balancing issues will inevitably occur.   As it stands though right now, it's a great and fun game to play either in PvP, Co-op, or campaign settings  that entices you  to actually pay for the premium account so that you can unlock expansion campaigns and extra loot.

Posted: October 18, 2015
												If you liked playing Banner Saga, then this game is pretty similar to it. This is a turn-based card strategy game. You form up three characters as a party to complete the campaigns and earn items in each battles. Even though this game has pay-to-win features and also memberships, but it hasn't affect much of the gameplay. You too can earn pizzas (cash currency) in certain rounds. You can either play it in a single player, where you command three characters. Or in a cooperative-gameplay, where three humans players control one character each. The campaign can seem rather boring as you get deeper into the jungle, as you need certain strategy in order to complete the round. Nevertheless this card game fuses together with item looting lets users to configure and mix-match their character abilities. The tutorial has been very helpful and witty at times, with an amateur player joking with the game master.For network connectivity, this game is pretty stable. Suitable for Asian players too, however it maybe hard to matchmake with co-op players due to the timezones.

Posted: July 17, 2015
												Pretty decent as far as turn based strategy RPGs go. The combat system is interesting since every action is determined by your cards, which are determined by your gear. A weapon might give a character more damaging cards, cards with more range or cards with special effects, armor works the same way for defensive and movement skills. All in all, it's ok to play in short bursts. The free to play model errs on the more expensive side, which is unfortunate since the genre isn't one where paid content would offer much over the free stuff.

Posted: July 17, 2015
												OK, when i first saw the game in PCGamer or something, i thought - "This game is probably full of microtransactions, as every free-to-play game. It looks childish, the genre is not my type... this is gonna suck". Before you know it, the game is installed. So i start it expecting to quit after 5-10 minutes. So we go to battle, i get a dwarf or some sh*t, who by the way walks like a retar*ed penguin. Next we have a magician who thinks he's Dumbledore. And we have a priest, or shaman or whatever. Ok this is like D&D, maybe it'll be fun. After like five turns not knowing what i'm doing, i'm like "i don't see myself playing this, probably gonna uninstall after the battle". So now i get the game, but guess what: i'm surrounded and i'm like "HEY! get away from my priest you a hole!" So i break the encirclement like the Ivan at Stalingrad, using the dovahkiin-looking warrior, mad dumbledore skills and fus-ro-dah teleportation skills. I WON! Maybe this isn't so bad after all. Next i face a big-as* dragon. Full of confidence i'm like : "Give me you best shot young Alduin" So now Alduin is spiting some sh*t on me, cant move, slowly dying. He approaches and now i'm like "fus-ro-dah motherf**ker" as i teleport him, i finish him off with my Tyrion Lannister-looking kind of guy. Battle is over and i scream: "In your face Alduin, who's the dovahkiin now, huh?" So my brother asks me: "What are you playing? I didn't know you had Skyrim installed" - "No, it's some D&D kind of game, i just rap*d Alduin" He loked at me with a strange, somewhat terrifying look, and after few seconds said "OK". My mom called me and asked if i was feeling alright.So yeah, this game turned out quite different than i expected, don't look at my playing time, i will definitely play a lot more of this game. You might think as a free-to-play game it must have microtransactions. Whell, acutally no. You can buy different types of versions that get you something, but nothing that changes the gameplay or give any significant advantage. If you have five minutes or wan't a marathon game, play it. It's free, fun and fair, which is not that common this days. this game was made because the devs love the games and the genre, making a very good game, try it.

												A very enjoyable single player game, and even more fun when you get to play with a couple of your buddies. This game brings the fun and joy of card games to your computer. When I play this, I get the feeling of DnD as well, especially with the special mission boards they give you. The game also has very good humor and jokes mixed in. Anyways, here are the basics. You can have fun playing as three different characters, a healer, a mage, and a warrior. From there, you can pick different races for the character, such as an elf, a human, or a dwarf. After you create the character, you get various equipment to put on your character to give them different cards. This is the general gameplay and setup and it's so satisfying trying to come up with strategies with the cards you have to win your matches. With this game being free and such, there is nothing lost at least giving this little gem of a game a try.

Posted: December 12, 2015
												In short: The classic boardgame interface is promising, but unfortunately the game feels terribly hurried.Cons- Some of the special missions rely, highly annoyingly, on pure card luck, ie. whether you got the right combo dealt or not- the novice gamemaster vs cynical old gamemaster joke gets old after a few rounds. Its repetitive and one-dimensional- you loot so insanely much items after every battle that the abundance makes you give up on thinking about your gear, leading you to just use whatever's "epic" or has the most hit points. I completely gave up on developing my characters in any meaningful way. This also makes the game repetitive and laborious. I dont think I bought more than one or two items. You really, really have to be into this type of games in order to find any sense in combing through tens and tens of meaningless-seeming objects.- the item menu is excuriating. Why not just offer the right type of items for each character, but instead forcing the user to browse all the menus to find each individual item category separately?- sound design is as stereotypical as humanly possible, as is the music. - There's no love in details in general, which makes the game seem generic and impersonal.Pros+ It's easy to play and sort of fun for the first few battles+ you can play it quite a bit without spending any money+ graphics breathe some warmth into the game+ suitable for kids+ Gary seems to be vegetarian :)

Posted: February 14, 2016
												So as of writing this, I'm roughly 10 hours in, and all the members in my party are level 8. I've only done the campaign(PVE) and only cleared the first lvl 7 area. This game is free, and I believe it is worth looking into. It has this somewhat captivating charm for people who enjoy turned based strategy games mixed with dice and cards or who just enjoy a game that somewhat parodies DnD stereotypes. Keep in mind that this game is not a 'traditional' card game, as in you build your deck by buying cards. Instead, you buy items to equip a character. These items add a number of different cards to your deck which you will draw from every so often. Items are found in chests at the end of each battle, bought in shops, or you can spend real cash to purchase loot boxes.Keep in mind, this is a free to play game so there are pay-to-win aspects. Such as buying the loot chests. Since your campaign and multiplayer(pvp) items transfer over. Though I need to stress that these 'chests' you can buy do not always give good items- the items are so varied in quality and combination in this game that making a setup with what you have can match someone who went out and just bought the majority of their gear through these randomized gamble-boxes.Pay to win aside, the game has a 'card hunter's club' membership that's just premium, all it does is drop one extra item- and they're not usually any good so far. Then they have the 'costume' shop. Some of the little models are nice, and I would buy a few of them, myself, if I had the cash to spend- if I wasn't already spending it all on other games. Hopefully, they might add a new skin or two in the future that might catch my eye.So with some of the bad and good out there, I'm going to make a quick Pros and Cons list.Pros- Entertaining 'story' one might expect of a parody to what the classic Stereotype of DnD players would be like.- Many adventures- A ton of them which can be played once, each, daily. - SO MUCH LOOT; Diablo style loot hunting game. Wide variation and combinations of loot dropped at the end of each battle.- Combat can be tough and unforgiving, especially if the dice hate you. Or it can all be turned around with one good dice roll.- Has Co-op. I LOVE co-op turn-based strategy, and this one just feels like it would do good(I have yet to try it, myself.)- Has multiplayer PvP, seems interesting. I've only played against the bot, though.Cons- Pay to Win. Though not as big of a deal as it is in most games. You won't be able to tell if they got it from a bought chest or from playing the game long enough.- Adventures have a refresh time, three battles each setup. No actual RPG elements aside from fighting, lvling, and equiping things.- No Co-op lobby, you just start Co-op and invite friends? I have yet to try it.- 3 classes: Warrior, Cleric, Wizard- 3 Races: Elf, Dwarf, HumanAll in all, for a free game, it is both simple and holds quite a bit of depth with what can be done. I do hope there is an actual table-top version of this. It looks fun. Also, it could do with more classes, maybe. Playing with the same three classes can get kind of old, but it's understandable that there aren't more. Race-wise, it's the rather standarad 3 fantasy races. But, again, more variation would be fun. All-in-all, there's still a lot to do here for such a simple game, and it's somewhat addictive.

												This game was exactly what I was looking for. I love card based games in the real world, but don't always have others to play against. This one will sometimes really make you think, as sometimes the cards you get won't be ideal - just like any real stategist game. Work with what you have. Posted: March 10, 2016
												Very cool game about a game.  D-n-Desque single and co-op that has a nice interface and unique (at least to me)  game play.  Basically you are playing against the DM on various maps and the goal is to complete 3 missions per scenario.  Each mission is progressively tougher.  It is your team against the DM.  In turn based combat you cast spells, attack, or move about the board to defeat the oponent or achieve specific goals.  You do this by drawing random cards from your deck.  Your deck is built, based upon the type of equipment you are wearing or using.  So a certain shield might give you three cards, two of which are defence and one offence.  A certain sword would give you 5 attacks.  As you get higher in level you are able to use better equipement and get better cards.  This is an excellent, simple, well put together game.  And it's free!  Of course you can make micro-purchases which I have done.  It helps get better equipment and scenarios (free game has a ton, though).  Mostly I made the purchase to support the developers.  An excellent and fun game that is worthy of earning some real coin.  I see some comments regarding a need to pay to progress.  Not true.  I have played solo and with freinds (max 3 per group so far).  We just now, at lvl 9+, decided to purchase items and only as support of devs.  Maybe this need is true at higher levels but even so, considering the time we have into it, I'd say the cost is very reasonable.

Posted: May 8, 2016
												I am not great at reviews.Card Hunter is basically a tactical-board game where you have three characters who each have their own deck composed of items that you equip to them and the character's race (of Human, Elf, Dwarf, I would be happy to see more, but I have played this game since before it was on Steam and it has only ever had the three).I am unaware of any pay to win aspects in the game. There are microtransactions, but they are cosmetic, or for expansion packs, which I am okay with. Most of the stuff you can buy seems reasonably priced to me, your mileage may vary.The game itself can be frustrating at times, as there is a lot of rng-madness going on. Some games you'll draw non-combat card after non-combat card despite having a deck on the character that consists of a great many combat cards. Other games you'll get a plethora of combat cards, but not enough ways to actually move to opponents, which leads to having to discard all of your lovely cards.Most matches run fairly well though, I have had many good runs where I felt everything went well, but when playing with rng, you are going to come up to points that are frustrating.The art style of the game is clear and enjoyable. The campaign story isn't terrible, though the meat of the game is the tactical combat, so the story isn't a major focus.I recommend the game, it is a good pick-up-and-play game, lightly casual, but with enough depth to sink into.

Posted: January 27, 2016
												A Dungeons and Dragons-type, isometric, overhead, retro, tactics game, Card Hunter has consumed about 3 months of my life. Players compete against AI and other humans over Steam or over the Browser and play cards to move, deal damage, heal hitpoints, or change the rules of the tiles players stand on, in a 3v3 or 3 vs bot arenas.  A simple overarching storyline tells the tale of Mary Mymax's game (a nod to the great Gary Gymax from Dungeons and Dragon's fame.)  A second expansion came out last summer.  There are halloween items and a christmas store, and new battles are fireing every 30 seconds successfully against players.  Come join the thousands of people to play this game. Personally, 4 out of my 6 rarest achievments out of 1600+ achievements are from Card Hunter, so you're taking the advice of an addict.

Posted: February 7, 2016
												I am far from finishing this game, but what I have played is very charming.  I like the fusion of old school paper and pencil (and miniature) role-playing, and collectible card game mechanics.  The cards in your deck, and the actions you can take, are all determined by the gear your character equips.  Everything in the game is touched with a humor that lightly mocks gamer culture nerdiness, while obviously also being a love letter to the same.  I like the art style, which kinda skirts the line between Munchkin art and classic old-school game art.  The most important thing is that it actually plays well, and is a lot of fun.Oh, also, its free to play.  So try it.

Posted: January 19, 2016
												It's a good mix between a Magic card game and old-school turn-based D&D games. This is the best free game I've ever gotten from Steam. There are so many bad games in this niche. This is a good one. The early encounters are fairly simple, but it rapidly increases into challenging but well-balanced strategic combats.The setting is a childhood D&D tabletop game so it's light-hearted but the game is extremely strategic and many of the encounters in the single player campaign are quite challenging. A couple seemed nearly impossible at first but then I took the time to change my gear to specifically meet the needs of that fight and I prevailed.   Very good game.

Posted: February 14, 2016
												So as of writing this, I'm roughly 10 hours in, and all the members in my party are level 8. I've only done the campaign(PVE) and only cleared the first lvl 7 area. This game is free, and I believe it is worth looking into. It has this somewhat captivating charm for people who enjoy turned based strategy games mixed with dice and cards or who just enjoy a game that somewhat parodies DnD stereotypes. Keep in mind that this game is not a 'traditional' card game, as in you build your deck by buying cards. Instead, you buy items to equip a character. These items add a number of different cards to your deck which you will draw from every so often. Items are found in chests at the end of each battle, bought in shops, or you can spend real cash to purchase loot boxes.Keep in mind, this is a free to play game so there are pay-to-win aspects. Such as buying the loot chests. Since your campaign and multiplayer(pvp) items transfer over. Though I need to stress that these 'chests' you can buy do not always give good items- the items are so varied in quality and combination in this game that making a setup with what you have can match someone who went out and just bought the majority of their gear through these randomized gamble-boxes.Pay to win aside, the game has a 'card hunter's club' membership that's just premium, all it does is drop one extra item- and they're not usually any good so far. Then they have the 'costume' shop. Some of the little models are nice, and I would buy a few of them, myself, if I had the cash to spend- if I wasn't already spending it all on other games. Hopefully, they might add a new skin or two in the future that might catch my eye.So with some of the bad and good out there, I'm going to make a quick Pros and Cons list.Pros- Entertaining 'story' one might expect of a parody to what the classic Stereotype of DnD players would be like.- Many adventures- A ton of them which can be played once, each, daily. - SO MUCH LOOT; Diablo style loot hunting game. Wide variation and combinations of loot dropped at the end of each battle.- Combat can be tough and unforgiving, especially if the dice hate you. Or it can all be turned around with one good dice roll.- Has Co-op. I LOVE co-op turn-based strategy, and this one just feels like it would do good(I have yet to try it, myself.)- Has multiplayer PvP, seems interesting. I've only played against the bot, though.Cons- Pay to Win. Though not as big of a deal as it is in most games. You won't be able to tell if they got it from a bought chest or from playing the game long enough.- Adventures have a refresh time, three battles each setup. No actual RPG elements aside from fighting, lvling, and equiping things.- No Co-op lobby, you just start Co-op and invite friends? I have yet to try it.- 3 classes: Warrior, Cleric, Wizard- 3 Races: Elf, Dwarf, HumanAll in all, for a free game, it is both simple and holds quite a bit of depth with what can be done. I do hope there is an actual table-top version of this. It looks fun. Also, it could do with more classes, maybe. Playing with the same three classes can get kind of old, but it's understandable that there aren't more. Race-wise, it's the rather standarad 3 fantasy races. But, again, more variation would be fun. All-in-all, there's still a lot to do here for such a simple game, and it's somewhat addictive.

Posted: March 9, 2016
												Once you get past the mandatory tutorial (which may seem a bit long, but will help you grip the mechanics of the game) this game is a treasure gem in recent RPGs.The graphics are really nice with their comic touch and also allow low-end computers to enjoy the game.The vast inventory of items that you can acquire is pure awesome.It is fun and addictive, and still very challenging. I found playing co-op with some friends really made the game even more awesome.While I would like more costumes (customization <3), those that are is quite cool. Downsides include the quite annoying "game master" that jumps around every now and then. He is fun in the tutorial, but we should be able to turn him off later on. The notion that you can pay to earn better gear is not good, but still doesn't break the game IMO. This is not a pay-to-win game, but it does give you an advantage in the beginning.

Posted: March 5, 2016
												The game starts off well enough, and is Thoroughly enjoyable. But by the time you hit level 6 you'll start noticing power discrepancies. By level 8, it has become a major annoyance, When you start getting close to level 10, you will find yourself consistently out numbered, starting in bad positions, against enemies that can deal far more damage than you can consistently and with defences that negate entire swaths of cards, and healing abilities far above your own. Eventually, it becomes unplayable.Worse, this is not the fault of bad gear and cannot simply be bought out of as with so called pay-to-win games. Good gear is abundant, you just can’t use any of it due to the horrible pedantic power node system.Looking at the game’s pedigree, including staff from Irrational Games/Looking Glass studios and advisers from Magic the Gathering, one of two things comes to mind. You would either expect the game to be phenomenal, or you still have painful memories of Bioshock: Infinite and Modern Format. Sadly, I have to say that it starts as the first and quickly moves towards the later.

Posted: March 10, 2016
												Very cool game about a game.  D-n-Desque single and co-op that has a nice interface and unique (at least to me)  game play.  Basically you are playing against the DM on various maps and the goal is to complete 3 missions per scenario.  Each mission is progressively tougher.  It is your team against the DM.  In turn based combat you cast spells, attack, or move about the board to defeat the oponent or achieve specific goals.  You do this by drawing random cards from your deck.  Your deck is built, based upon the type of equipment you are wearing or using.  So a certain shield might give you three cards, two of which are defence and one offence.  A certain sword would give you 5 attacks.  As you get higher in level you are able to use better equipement and get better cards.  This is an excellent, simple, well put together game.  And it's free!  Of course you can make micro-purchases which I have done.  It helps get better equipment and scenarios (free game has a ton, though).  Mostly I made the purchase to support the developers.  An excellent and fun game that is worthy of earning some real coin.  I see some comments regarding a need to pay to progress.  Not true.  I have played solo and with freinds (max 3 per group so far).  We just now, at lvl 9+, decided to purchase items and only as support of devs.  Maybe this need is true at higher levels but even so, considering the time we have into it, I'd say the cost is very reasonable.

Posted: March 15, 2016
												Great game full of nerdy D&D fun. There are plenty of pay to players out there, but due to the ranking system you don't have to fight them if you don't want to pay to play. The whole game depends on giving your characters equipment that works together, making an effective strategy in the match, and perhaps most of all, pure luck. I have beaten players many ranks higher than me, and have been beaten by players many ranks lower than me. This game is designed well enough to separate the pay to players and the casual players. Anyone who gripes about pay to players probably just doesn't know how to strategize effectively or work with the cards they're given. The league matches with prebuilt decks are where a players true colors show. Many times I have beaten higher ranked players when given even playing fields.Overall its a really fun game if you don't take it too seriously. Also there is an editor where you can build your own maps and scenarios which is awesome.

Posted: January 6, 2016
												Update - beat the main campaign and some extra paid content (citadel highest levels), there is really not much left to do after you get to maxed level party (and leveling a new party member is quite a nightmare). The replayability is made through "quests" (e.g. all your guys have 1hp/one death and you lose e.t.c), for which YOU DO NOT GET EXPERIENCE on your dudes, which is a big factor.Online multiplayer is 6/10 for me, with "Draft mode" - called quick draw would be 7/10 IF it didn't take so long to draft in the first place. So each draft "tournament" is at least 4 games (up to infinite), where you and your opponent have to draft 21 skills before every match, which takes around 12-20minutes.There is really no point that we have to redraft abilities before every match in such tournaments.For the lack of true end game and forcing to draft new abilities before every match I'd in the end rate it boderline positive, still it is very close to a negative review, the game IS fun for the first playthrough, until you hit the end game.____ Previous review (positive)The game is quite fun, difficulty is in presence. While many challenges are suited for specific sets/playstyles you may still get through them with your typical sets.Note that this game isn't really completely F2P, quite a lot of content is behind paywall.

												I enjoy this game alot not only because I like turn-based strategy games; but that the system itself is fairly balancing (items tend to have upsides and downsides), there are clear strategies for defeating different types of enemies and that its not exactly pay-to-win.The club membership itself does get you more items; but from what I've seen, they arent usually as good as what you get in the chest anyways, but that still helps you make some extra coin anyways from selling the stuff (which honestly is way better than the club membership items being so good that you feel like you have to join)Im usually not the type of person to invest money in games; but I've purchased all the DLC for this game because our how much I enjoy it.I highly reccommend this game.As a side note, the DLC not only adds the new quests; but the cards featured in the new sets start popping up in random loot chests, so its definetely worth investing in to see all the unique cards.

												An excellent buy for the price of nothing! The game has a sense of rewarding tactics (Hot Spot all the way!), and nice board-gamey feel. Posted: July 20, 2015
												I'm going to start off by saying that I really love this game! Even though it may seem repetitive, I have not yet become even the slightest bit bored at any point, and I currently have a level 10 team, so not too bad so far considering I've had the game for two days! Campaign Mode - Okay, so with this mode, we're accompanied by Gary and Melvin, two 'CPU' versions of the card/board game competitors. Some of their lines are actually really funny, and they've not annoyed me yet which is surprising consdiering everything annoys me haha. Basically, what's great about campaign is that, at first, it's really easy to win and learn how to play, but once you start to get the hang of things, it becomes more difficult - to the point where it may take more than one attempt to beat the level - and this is obviously a technique to prevent boredom. The levels are of course possible, but they are challenging and require you to be strategic, which I love. There are many shops with many different types of weaponary and equipment, most of which are affordable. The characters have great customisation, including names which I think is a great detail, though it's small. It really feels like the team is yours and you know everything they can and can't do. Speaking of the characters, there are three per party. A warrior, mage and priest (healer). I'll explain the main pros and cons of each that I've noticed.Warrior: Pros - Good attacks and defenses, Cons - You have to be up close to use the attacks which makes your warrior vulnerable to attacksMage: Pros - Attacks from a distance, Cons - Low health, no armourPriest: Pros - Can heal the whole team repeatedlty, Cons - Not a lot of good attacks and defensesBut yeah, overall for campaign, everything is really great - characters, equipment, weaponary, levels, difficulty, even the dialogue is fun haha.Multiplayer Mode - I haven't played too much of this mode, but overall I like this too. You're always matched against someone on a similar multiplayer level as you, which makes the match fair, and everyone's team is levelled to the exact same also. Since in this mode your team is at the highest level, you can pretty much use whichever weapons you want to, whereas you can't do that in campaign as the level you are at limits what you use to fight with, which is understandable levelling. But the weapons you use in multiplayer mode are what you own in campaign mode, but both parties are different in each mode if you want them to be. So yeah, I definitely recommend getting this game if you like this kind of thing, and hey, it's free, what do you have to lose?

Posted: July 16, 2015
												When I had made it through my first hour of gameplay I quickly returned to the store page to write a short  review about how much better this game was than trying to play a boring old table top. But now after more than 12 hours sunk into card hunter I find it harder to recomend. The story is funny and the characters are cheesy enough to feel like real nerds. But after a while the game looses all sense of expansion. Or to put that another way: it runs out of fresh ideas very quickly. After you finish the first level you have literally done everything there is to do in this game. Kill everything on the table, play an attack card for 10 damage that looses 9 points of its power to the 4 armor cards that every enemy has. Thats it. By all means play this game. Its good for a few hours of fun for people like me who cant stand DND, but for gods sake dont go thinking this can ever compare to a serious table top campaign. I know people that have games that are over 2 years old and still going. So yeah. Good time killer, just dont expect to get too invested in it.

												I have to say I really like this game.  Lots of nostalgic feelings from my old D&D days of pen and paper play.  It has a neat system which is easy to learn but has some room for learning to become really good at it.  I play with my friends and it is a blast, especially when you get defeated by a scenario and have to rethink strategy and card deck to over come it (hopefullY) on the second, sometimes third, try.  I truly think that the negative reviews are from people that just arent very good at this type of game, or just arent very bright.  Luck is a part of it but not as much as some people say.  And hey, its free!

Posted: August 27, 2016
												Disclosure: I'm Renown level 10 with a character at level 11.Like I'm prone to say with any game that allows it: play this with friends. The ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t is best witnessed with two buddies by your side.And I say "♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t", but this game's usage of dicerolls and randomization is less egregious than many other examples I've seen. This, with all the rogue♥♥♥♥♥♥games out on the market today, ought to be high-♥♥♥♥ing-praise, honestly.The tactics involved are organic and the ruleset is entirely reasonable. Block and armor cards (the major sources of RNG pain) have several counters and they're all good.I don't care about competitive multiplayer and neither do my friends. You really ought not to in this game anyways, since the baseline of competitive play requires max-level characters and equipment.10/03/2016I have found out that PVP does not require max level characters. All PVP characters are set to level 18, rather, where characters are given 8 power tokens, four blue and four orange.The actual maximum level goes far beyond that but has no bearing on PVP.So to amend: Don't worry about competitive multiplayer until your characters hit 18. You won't have the equipment to compete before then anyway, and the lessons you learn about the game's systems along the way are valuable.

Posted: September 29, 2016
												I balked hard when the friend who recommended Card Hunter to me said the name, and admitted that card-based gameplay is involved. I really, really, really, really, repeat it a few more times, dislike deck-building games, virtual or otherwise. Aside from various other considerations, I just don't have FUN with them; tag-wise, I think only "Point-And-Click" and "MOBA" make me back-arrow out of a game's store page faster than anything to do with cards.Well, he talked me into playing Card Hunter anyway. And you know what? I'm really glad he did. It does involve deck-building, not in quite the way I expected, and I'm still not crazy about that part. But the game as a whole is amusingly designed and fun to play. My best team is only up to level 10 or so, so I can't vouch for later on, and I'm not much into PVP so I haven't tried that, although the co-op play was interesting. So far, it feels like a game I'll keep coming back to to play again... color me amazed. :)

Posted: August 27, 2016
												Card Hunter is a pretty fun TBST (Turn Based Stadegy game) that dosent take itself too seriously.Pros:+Fun, somewhat relaxing gameplay+A good sense of humor+An easy game to pick up and play.Cons:-At only 2 hours in, I'm already seeing it's "paid prividges" leaking through it's free to play skinSo mainly my problem with the game is that their are a lot of things I'm seeing the devs tring to peddle to you as a way for you to spend money, but really, the amount they ask for isn't too much. I mean, the pizza slices (the "premium cash") seem overpriced, but I havent really sunk my teeth into the paid part of the game yet, so I don't know, maybe 10 dollars for 330 pizza slices isnt that much, and 10 dollars to play more maps dosent seem like much anyways. I would reccomend this game to anyone who wants a nice casual experince with a mix of D&D like graphics, card gameplay a little like hearthstone, or just a casual tbsg.

Posted: May 8, 2016
												I am not great at reviews.Card Hunter is basically a tactical-board game where you have three characters who each have their own deck composed of items that you equip to them and the character's race (of Human, Elf, Dwarf, I would be happy to see more, but I have played this game since before it was on Steam and it has only ever had the three).I am unaware of any pay to win aspects in the game. There are microtransactions, but they are cosmetic, or for expansion packs, which I am okay with. Most of the stuff you can buy seems reasonably priced to me, your mileage may vary.The game itself can be frustrating at times, as there is a lot of rng-madness going on. Some games you'll draw non-combat card after non-combat card despite having a deck on the character that consists of a great many combat cards. Other games you'll get a plethora of combat cards, but not enough ways to actually move to opponents, which leads to having to discard all of your lovely cards.Most matches run fairly well though, I have had many good runs where I felt everything went well, but when playing with rng, you are going to come up to points that are frustrating.The art style of the game is clear and enjoyable. The campaign story isn't terrible, though the meat of the game is the tactical combat, so the story isn't a major focus.I recommend the game, it is a good pick-up-and-play game, lightly casual, but with enough depth to sink into.

Posted: October 14, 2015
												Ok, lets get this straight to avoid any confusion.  This game has nothing to do with roleplaying games, but what it does have a lot to do with is classic fantasy boardgames, like talisman, dungeon, or heroquest.  Unfortunately this is marred by the whole having to pay to unlock certain features and bonuses, and in the pvp section this really does show as to who pays and who's here just for fun. There are a few stereotypes which immediately feel out of place, especially as this isn't 1986 and games like this are far more mainstream these days, so the depiction of everyone who plays this as a nerd hurts more than helps.Ok, on to the game itself, past the cringe-worthy imagery.  What I will say here is that everything that follows is why I gave it a  positive thumb waving.They have for the most part, got themselves a really good package here, with board based tile movement and card based combat.  You fight all of the fantasy stereotypes of goblins, orcs and other such things.  The combat is resolved by using cards for each adventurer that you have until you find you can't use any more, due to running out, or just not having the right card at the right time, like in the video where the guy says 'I cast a lightning bolt!' etc.  At the end of every round the adventurers and remaining monsters get to draw new cards.  This can be a little difficult to catch when the game uses the terms 'rounds' and 'turns' applying htem to what they want.  Movement can only take place if you have movement cards, and I don't see any indicator to show when you're arriving at the end of the round.  So tactics like waiting for the monsters to move and expend their cards for movement/attack before you make your decisions aren't really possible.  If you do try to estimate that, then you could end up in a poor position, as if you have over two cards per adventurer left at the end of the turn, then you have to discard them until you have the sacred number of 2 for some reason.The amount of money you gain is determined by how much treasure detritis you find after each battle, which usually comes in quite low amounts, so most of the time you will depend on the other treasure items you find to equip your adventurers.I would recommend this game, but only if you want a very superficial experience and aren't looking for anything with more depth than your 12 year old brother might be looking for in a fantasy board game.   Maybe good for an hour on the weekend with your favourite intoxicant/food-snack while still wearing your p.js perhaps.

Posted: November 23, 2016
												Card Hunter is an awsome game. You can play it solo, coop, and PvP ; all modes are fun !  It looks like an DnD adventure, where you have rounds, an you and the enemy take turns to play. You may play cards from you're hand, which changes every turn (since you draw), and those cards come from the build you give to each characters.This kind of building allows you to create a lot of different possible options, which makes running the game over and over again, like if you'd played for the first time ! :)You can play the game without paying anything, though the dlc gives more maps to play through, which is kind of fun.If I could suggest any buys, I would recommand the first "Basic Edition" game, and the other AI Bundle (5,99$). This way, you should make enough pizza to buy all the other maps from Citadel (require only when you reach max level) without paying (if I'm not mistaken). Though buying the second dlc gives another subscription month and some kool figurines. You're call ^^Whatsoever, this games has my vote ! Always fun to play, mostly coop, with friends or people online. Enjoy !

Posted: October 30, 2016
												Nice game with some tactical possibilities.However, when you draw 'bad' cards, it can be hard to win some fights.On the other hand, I like the overall design and how the different races/ classes 'feel' and act on the battlefield.Some of the user-designed missions are more like a puzzle, at first it seems impossible to beat the scenario, but after some thinking - and sometimes with some luck - it works.All of your party members (3 in total) can use different gear that grants cards. In addition, you gain power points at higher levels that can be used to equip special items or wield better weapons and armor. There are quite a lot of customizing possibilities for your characters, thanks to the card loadout granted by different items.So my thumbs up, give it a try, it's fun.

Posted: November 23, 2016
												A bit of an hidden gem that is a great mix of Dungeons & Dragons and deck building. Its free to play so the pay part comes in when you want to unlock more adventures. There is technically enough adventures that you can continue to play for free for a while but it does limit things a bit. You can grind their in-game currency to "buy" the adventures but plan on putting in a bit of time to do that.Seems like a great casual game to play with friends and sink some time into with decent progression. If you don't like the pre-planning part of deck building then this might not be for you as you sometimes have to customize your character differently for every single mission and your super rare cards might not always be the best for every scenario.

Posted: January 30
Card Hunter is a Daemonic Hellspawn LoveChild of those dungeon hunting games and a nerd whom collects WoW merch's wet dream. Its a TBS that puts you in a world where the game is a board game and the game has board game vibes. You play as yourself and you pick 3 characters to play, Warrior, Mage, Monk and 3 races, elf, dwarf and human. Each Race is better suited for a certain role, Elf is good for magic, human for monk and dwarf for warrior. Its a solid game with each dungeon/map/board completed (which may have 3 or so stages) rewarding you with items and money. It features a huge selection of gear, to max health give you new cards and things. Its not P2w, even though i haven't seen any PvP (if there is) and even if you don't get The legendary  Cardboard Shield and Larp sword Gear you may be able to buy it off others.

Posted: March 13, 2016
												I am reviewing the single-player component. I am too misanthropic to play this on multi-player (that's what why I play Red Orchestra 2: if I'm going to clobber someone, I want some gore). As a single-player game, I found Card Hunter to be a fun combination of deck-building and RPG dungeon crawler. While there are "pay-to-play" elements, they aren't necessary to advance in the game. I did pay for some of them, in part to support the creation of new modules. The scenarios or modules are reminiscent of many old basic, 1st and 2nd edition D&D or AD&D modules by TSR (before they were run into the ground by nepotistic hacks who hired their relatives and ran off Gary E. Gygax, and in turn were acquired by corporate-controlled game companies). If you are an old pen-and-paper role-player and like nostalgic games with some innovation, try this.

Posted: February 4
												While some may not appreciate the style of the game, as someone who doesn't normally enjoy card games, I have found this to be quite a fun game. The adventures and the characters continue to be interesting for a long time, at least in my eyes. Though the rewards for quests are often rather... unrewarding, the difficulty of the game still progresses smoothly as your party levels up. The choices of your cards as well as your strategy on the battlefield are actually more influential in most cases than the luck mechanic of the game. Despite its flaws, Card Hunter is provided for free and is at least somewhat enjoyable. Thus, I find it hard not to recommend.
