Posted: March 1
												Awesome game. Been playing Card Hunter off and on for a few months now. Have never gotten bored of it due to the variety of quests and treasure quests, in fact I'm enjoying it more now than ever. I should say however that I'm only level 9 with one party of adventurers, have not yet spent any money on the game or felt the need too, (thought as I'm enjoying it so much I'm planning to buy a few Pizza slices soon) and have not even tried Multi-player yet.It is a wonderful and very easy to pick up card/turn-based combat type game.Would highly recommend it to any who love Hearthstone and the like, I was a big fan of Scrolls and since that died Card Hunter has replaced it quite nicely. It should also appeal to turn-based combat fans of the Heroquest/Warhammer Quest ilk.Love the art style and the sense of humour too and it's clearly a well-supported game with a great community too.

Posted: April 21
												   I've played Dungeons and Dragons in some form for pretty much my entire life, before I knew the official rules and had the friends to play (about 6-7 years old) I'd actually make my own version based on stories my dad and uncle would tell me about when they played in high school. Eventually I got older and bought my own copy of the DM Guide and Players Handbook and would play with friends. This game captures both of those experiences. But what really makes me enjoy the game more is the little details they add that only a true dice rolling dungeoneer would know about (the older brother yelling at you for using his characters and then mocking of your campaign or calling the same pizza place over and over to get the cute girl delivery but being afraid to talk to her, and many others)The card based combat system is very easy to pick up, but it takes a little bit longer to develop proper tactics based on your deck. If you are looking for a card game like Magic the Gathering then this is not for you, but if you have ever played Dungeons and Dragons or any other pen and paper style role playing game then I recommend trying it out for a little bit.

Posted: April 21
												With this game I was initially surprised by how much I was enjoying it. Pulled in by the strangely endearing Gary character and his seemingly elitest brother Melvin. The card system itself was really nice and I was always eager to see what set of cards I'd draw each turn and see how I'd use them. Honestly the basic mechanics of the game itself are really nice for what it is, although a tad too heavy on the RNG even for someone like myself who rather enjoys that sort of thing. I really only found the RNG to be annoying and it never truly crossed into obnoxious territory, but it certainly would have helped to have a little more strategy and predictability than is offered. Holding over 2 cards is nice...but it was pretty rare for me to find myself trying to decide between cards and most of the time just shredding extra move cards or just 'the weaker' of two.Don't get me wrong I'm glad there is 'SOME' predictability, but it does roll into annoying territory that you don't get the choice of 'gauranteeing' a card type each turn or something of the sort since sometimes I'd have a hand full of move cards, toss most of em and then next turn pull even more god damned move cards. There should be a flex system to allow you to pick at the end of each turn for each character what card you want to gaurantee you will pull. That would satisfy me personally and rid me of the sighs.Theres mostly adventures with your party that you build up over time and they're all pretty enjoyable. You can even co op with friends (though the system needs to allow 2 players to get 3 party members. That's stupid that you can't.). I also feel like I'd be a little happier with a fourth class and fourth character slot, but I'm ok if it doesn't have it. Guess this is as good as any place to mention there are elves and that just makes me happy. Wish you could change the damn color schemes to them though. I seen alternate color schemes so I know they exist, but I'm guessing they're only for special encounters or pvp.Also I don't like the 'custom adventures'. I think some of them are horrendously imbalanced and designed. They wouldn't be anywhere near as frustrating if they were 'one offs' but most of them are groups of them, like 3 at a time and in order to get through them you have to do them all in one swoop. It works fine and dandy when it's YOUR PARTY and you can adjust your characters to suit the encounter, but not in special challenges where you're essentially figuring out a puzzle. Beat the first two and stuck trying to figure out how to beat the last one? Well ♥♥♥♥ you.I know before I said that I liked Gary and Melvin, but I do have to say that the two started to wear on me a bit down the line with both of them being a little too stereotypical for my tastes. I guess the 'childlike wonder' effect wore off on me a little early though so I wouldn't take my word on it. I might be a little too chiseled around the edges know what I mean?So you must be wondering why the review SEEMS so positive, but is negative right? Well I can't in good conscience give a game with gambling and P2W a good review. Sorry. The game has online vs and it's based on buildable characters and items that you can buy with 'pizza slices' (awesome premium currency name btw). I'm totally down with omitting 'adventures' as paid content, that's fine. This game really feels pretty heavy on singleplayer too so yah. Unfortunately since you can pay real money to buy 'chests' that will give gear I can't give it a positive review. I ain't down with that. It makes it worse that there is pvp too.In the end though it's actually a pretty cool game and I think I will play it more. I mean up until I get really frustrated with the RNG or some♥♥♥♥♥♥ If you got the time though you should probably at least check it out. Couldn't hurt right? It's F2P as they say.
